We still wouldn't have free-will. Either there are antecedent reasons that affect what we do, or there aren't. If there are, those reasons are why we do what we do, not our will. If our will has somehow to do with evaluating these reasons (freely or not), then either there are reasons for how we evaluate as we do, or there aren't. If there are, then those reasons are why we evaluate as we do, not our will. If there are ever a lack of reasons, then caprice interjects himself. Do we mean to say that our having free-wills lies in our caprice?

Of course, the incoherence of free-will is only one problem. There are others. And the mere possibility of the universe having these random generative bursts of stuff, though highly interesting, doesn't answer any of these problems. Take, for example, the observation that if our thoughts are somehow random, then we somehow lack control over them. Where's our freedom in that? Or is freedom constrained, in which case it isn't freedom?

Maybe worth clarifying a couple of things. First, there is "randomness" of ignorance (in other words, if you don't understand the pattern, something seems random) versus "true" randomness (which sure seems to be the case in quantum...but then we may not understand a deeper deterministic reality, as Einstein hoped). Rolling a die seems random, but only because we aren't capable of measuring everything about the die accurately enough to predict the result if it goes through enough tumbles - no quantum mechanics required.

Second, we typically explain the 2nd law by pointing out that for a somewhat ordered system, it can move to any of many possible states that are more disordered that the starting point, but relatively few that are more ordered, so that simple probability takes us toward disorder. However, as Sean Carroll has pointed out, that may be simply because we live in a relatively ordered universe, compared to what it could be (what folks call the "heat death" of the universe of maximum entropy). Is the second law just a product of the fact that there is still quite a bit of order left in the cosmos, and most possible changes are more disordered...?

However, I don't believe that any of the conclusions presented in the video lead to the idea of free will. The universe is very unpredictable and has many aspects to it that are truly random, but that does not make our will free. We are complex organisms and can do very complex things, but they are not free from outside influences, even when some of those influences are truly random. We have will, but it is not free.

I’m having trouble with the semantics of “randomness” and “disorder” being the same thing, randomness being particularly the slippery word. Even if it was random quantum events in the brain I’m not sure that qualifies as free Will. There seems to be differences in the ways people define “random” so I would need clarification - for example there is random in the sense of someone rolling 2 dice, and because we lack the knowledge of things like the exact conditions of the air, the force used on the dice, how the surface material would interact on the dice, and many other factors we would call that random because we are ignorant of these factors and can’t predict it because of this. Then there is random in the sense where an effect has no prior cause - this is the one that I don’t see evidence for, even if it appears that way in quantum mechanics we may just not know yet** what causes them.

I don't agree with the premise that entropy = information. It seems to be assuming itself to be true to prove itself to be true. If there was no randomness, you would not need more information to describe the universe in the future vs. the universe now. The universe now is (the big bang +x time units). The universe in the future is (the big bang +x+1 time units). This allows for more entropy but no more information is required to describe its state (the only information required would be the state of the universe prior to the big bang and the number of time units you want to have passed). Envision a formula that determines every attribute of a particle based the initial state of the big bang and time passed. If the number of fundamental particles (whatever that is) has remained the same since the big bang, the number of calculations is unchanged so the amount of information is unchanged.

So if there is randomness, entropy=information. If there isn't, entropy=/=information. You can't say "there is randomness in quantum physics, therefore the future requires more information, therefore there is randomness in the universe". I feel like the whole argument is based on the assumption that randomness exists in the first place. If randomness does not exist there is no difference in the information contained in each fundamental particle (and even if randomness does exist, does it affect these particles?).

Randomness does not rescue the outdated concept of "free will" because things that are random are not "free" any more than things that are predictably caused. Other than this point of dispute, is a good video. It would seem that there is not much to say about "randomness", but it is actually a deep subject that you could write books about.

From high school science classes, I had concluded that you could theoretically determine the entire future with enough data, until I later learned that this was a philosophy that had a name, of "determinism". After learning more about quantum physics, I realized that the philosophy was wrong.

By the time that you have 12 "fundamental" particles, part of what that tells you is that whatever these things are, they are not "fundamental". What Einstein was saying in so-many words about reducing our understanding of reality to the minimum of "fundamentals" would seem to have left unsaid that the most satisfying reduction would be to unity. Maybe that unity would be in string theory, or in Higgs field, but it seems to defy reason that "unity" could ever split into a dozen.

The early attempt at identifying "fundamentals" as earth, wind, fire and water was both insightful and half-baked silliness at the same time. Atoms got us a hit closer as "fundamental", but then it started breaking down to protons, electrons, and neutrons, which then started breaking down into quarks. Perhaps our search for fundamentals only discovers the limits of our ability to observe things.

I remember a guy in my college dorm, a half-century ago, remarking that it was a bias, not necessarily so, that underlying reality had to be simple. It would probably blow his mind that a casual comment like that stuck in my mind for 50 years. I see his point, but still feel in deep gut that the "bias" is righteous.

If I were trying to stare at reality naively, like the ancient Greeks, with little to go on, I might have supposed that there were two fundamental forces in conflict: a force of order, as in perfect circles and triangles, and a force of disorder, causing any real-world representation of a circle or triangle to be imperfect.

My best guess of universal origin is the existence of the "uncaused event". This would not be "randomness" in the sense of a coin toss, where outcome is really determined by subtle factors on which we do not have enough data, but an event that literally has no cause.

Infinite randomness, like monkeys banging randomly on typewriters, does not just reproduce the works of Shakespeare. It writes the Book of Genesis, giving rise even to marvels of human brain and immune system.

Randomness x Infinity = Creation

We will probably never get a more succinct expression of universal creation than this "equation".

Everything is determined by a HUGE set of causes that we can't predict or even being aware about how many there are, because you know, the world is complex and all. And of course, we may know some of these causes.
In other words, we have some but not all previous information that can help us (deterministic) and information that we don't know (non-deterministic or "noise") that will result in some event that we want to predict. So, simple speaking, statistics aim to use the information that we know and use it to reduce the uncertain of the noise we have and therefore, make inference about our event of interest.

There is something left out in this video. High entropy doesn't mean something is random in the sense that it would not be predetermined. Pi for example has maximal entropy, it appears perfectly random, but of course it isn't. Pi can be defined in a very compact manor. In the video he uses this idea of the minimal description of something to define its complexity. But that is not entropy, it is a different measure of information called Kolmogorov complexity.
So just because the universe appears random, it does not mean it is. This same insight is at the core of chaos theory, that investigates deterministic systems that exhibit apparently random, impossible to predict behavior.

This video seems to suffer from a few misunderstandings. It is true that quantum mechanics is a probabilistic theory and that a deterministic one would prohibit the existence of free will (though it is not clear at all how free will might arise from a probabilistic theory either). However, modern quantum statistical mechanics actually predicts that the entropy of isolated systems is constant, not increasing, so the bits mentioning the second law of thermodynamics are misleading at best. According to modern quantum statistical mechanics, it is only the entropy of subsystems that increases over time (on average, in generic systems), and the principal mechanism behind this increase is entanglement generation through coherent evolution, not measurement-induced collapse of quantum-mechanical wave functions. Outside of highly curated laboratory environments, every system is in appreciable contact with its environment, so everything we observe is effectively a subsystem, and the observations of classical thermodynamics arise in the classical limit.

I am not convinced that the second law implies the information in the universe increases. Isn't physical entropy based on a dichotomy between macro and micro states? I.e. the macro state of a completely mixed drink has very many micro states (configurations of individual particles in the drink), so has high entropy, vs a low entropy state where the macro state is more specific and the micro configurations are more constrained. If we don't make this distinction, can we measure information in the same way? A drink can unstir itself, it's just ridiculously unlikely, right? Isn't there some kind of premise or presupposition we have to make before we can talk about information, like the underlying probability distribution, which might not meaningfully exist in a deterministic system?

There is a give and take between the Message and "compression algorithm"  The more complex and robust the algorithm the more compressed the output is. This is a very interesting video and there are some points I would like to make.

Just because something seems random, or doesn't have a pattern doesn't mean it is. Let's analyze that bit compression example. So let's say we have an image and we compress it to the point that the result seems random. But that result really is not random because it is predictable. If the core of information is this compressed result, and the result is random then that means the arrangement of the pixels was random to begin with, or the scene before the picture was taken was random. How the scene was put together could be random or not, the fact that the compressed information seems random (or rather has no pattern) doesn't really prove anything in my opinion.

Also, entropy is describes dissorder but I don't think that it generates information or randomness at all. On the contrary, I think that disorder could be seemingly random but that's just because most decaying systems are chaotic and thus impossible to be predicted in any reasonable time by anyone. The double pendulum that is shown at the end is such a system, chaotic that is, not because there are not theories and equations as to how it will move, or that anyone of them is based on probability, but because the math gets really complicated really quick and the initial conditions turn out to be a big part of it's movement (as the video stated).

Finally, I believe there is a theory that states information cannot be generated or lost (no-hiding theorem). That adds to the point that information and randomness are not one and the same. So even if entropy increases as the second law of thermodynamics states, that still doesn't mean Laplace's Demon couldn't exist.

Anyway, I choose to believe that we live in a deterministic world, not claiming that this is right, just my belief. A fully deterministic but chaotic world or a probabilistic one makes no difference to a macroscopic level in everyday life anyway, and I think it is more of a philosophical question. Whether free will is an illusion or not should play no role in anyone's life.

These possibilities are so large and the set itself is almost infinite that we think it's happening in random. Just to give an example of how large a set of arrangements of the letters A, B, C and D can be if we have to make an arrangement such that it contains 4 letters, the set without total repetitions (meaning all 4 of the letters cannot be repeated, although maximum 3 of them can be and less), we get a set having 252 elements, each having 4 letters. If we consider that all 4 letters can be repeated, the set enlarges to 256 elements. That is just 4 words forming arrangements such that each arrangement has 4 letters. If we look into the arrangements individually, we find arrangements like AABD, AAAB, ABCA, etc which appear completely 'random' while if we write the whole set down we find that all these elements are arranged in a sequence having first letter A common. What if the particles in quantum mechanics are arranged similarly, but the set is so large having arrangements of huge no. of elements and we know so little of it that we think the arrangements of the particles we observe are 'random'? randomness and chaos are two totally DIFFERENT things.

Randomness is pure; it cannot be determined. On the other hand, chaotic systems are deterministic, meaning if we know all the initial conditions, we can predict the outcome. However, that involves so much information (we cannot comprehend that) that we consider it as being random.

For FREE WILL:
There are two cases, if we consider everything as chaotic, then our behaviour and our choices are not random. they are deterministic, meaning if we know all the conditions, then we could predict the future. While if we consider them as being pure random, well you know how it goes.


MY STATEMENT:
In my belief, the quantum world and the pure randomness must be implemented in the laws of classic physics. Since classic physics is like a child of modern physics. For example, you could look upon the theories of quantum biology in which a quantum leap could lead to a DNA gene mutation, and voila, randomness is introduced to the physical macroscopic world. So it's not that simple. In the end, there are elements of randomness contributing to the world, which I believe leads to free will.

I might be totally wrong with this. But by Shannon's "information" what we mean is NOT about randomness, but "random" is just a factor how much we can/can't compress(optimize) the available "data" for representation(to parsed with a certain mathematical or algorithm, just like video codec or zip/unzip formulas).

But in real world, this information means nothing, because there's no point of representing the data(structure) of snapshot of the universe(@6:03) at any point of time. For example, lets say at time T1, there is a cloud of atoms in proximity at rest(or <escape velocity of the cloud). So data(snapshot) at T1 is just all the 3d coordinates of all the atoms. But by gravitational law we know at some point those atoms will converge to form a sphere, lets say at time T2. In Shannon's terms, the information now would be far less than at T1 because the coordinates are not as random anymore, and can be compressed.

So clearly, Information varies even though we have have entire information at T1. Not sure we can draw a flat horizontal line in @6:03

A computer simulation of quantum mechanics needs to make use of a random number generator, but modification of the Schroedinger equation is prohibited. This is just stating the obvious, but it looks as if we have contradictory rules to comply with. The resolution of the contradiction is to note that there is more than one way to travel faster than light. The Schroedinger equation describes an oscillation in the way that exchanges timelike and spacelike intervals. In the way that exchanges energy and momentum we can have tachyonic Brownian motion which is of course strictly orthogonal to the wavelike behaviour. TBM goes into action when the Schroedinger equation interacts with Maxwell's equation, and this is the origin of entropy increase. It is also the mechanism by which we go from the deterministic Schroedinger equation to the situation where that cat is either strictly dead or strictly alive.

I open to other ideas on how to use a RNG in computer simulation. In the macroscopic world we can just throw away the Schroedinger equation and replace it by classical Brownian motion on the same scale. Can anyone think of anything else?

Pragmatically we have to say people have free will otherwise it goes down a disempowering rabbit hole. 1. Everything on a micro scale is predictable and god does not play dice.

2. Order on a macro scale is a result of disorder in a micro scale.

3. Entropy exists, but reversed.
So instead of:
Order —> disorder
It’s
Disorder —> order

I think the parallel that this video draws between randomness and entropy is a bit spurious. If I had a binary string where I randomly select 1% of bits to be 1s, and then handed you half of the string, then you could make no predictions about the contents of the second half of the string from the first. So the string is completely random. However the entropy of the string is not complete. The string is mostly 0s and the string could be represented in a more compact form. Entropy is not randomness. Entropy is disorder. They are slightly different concepts.

2:36 "pure information is randomness" No way! A set of random 0s and 1s contains maximum information according to this video. It's meaningless information, then. So, not really information. To us, random bits is maximum information because of the absence of pattern, structure. One bit can't make us deduce what the next bit should be. That a non-random set of bits can be compressed doesn't mean it has less information than the original one, otherwise decompressing would lead to meaningless data. A random set of 0s and 1s can't be compressed because it contains no information, therefore no algorithm can be invented to compress it. So, yes, a file of random bits can't be compressed.

This video just annoys me because it reminds me of a failed argument I had with a stuck up chemist. We were arguing over the roll of dice. I posed the argument that randomness doesn't exist. We live in a deterministic universe. Probability simply exists because we lack the ability to model every possible factor that goes into a dice roll that would let us know what number it lands on. She couldn't comprehend that and kept talking about how she could write the probability out for me...

Had I had more competence and kept going i perhaps could have explained with a coin example. Heads and tails both have a probability of 50%. Adding up both gives 100%, but what if the coin lands on it's edge? It can happen but this over simplistic usage of probability assumes it is therefore impossible.

Or what about 'loaded' dice or coins i.e. cheating props that make it more likely for it to land a certain way by playing with weight distribution. Are you going to claim the die that has been altered to be more likely to land on a 6 still has a 1/6th chance at landing on a 6?

1. Information theory's entropy is not the same as the thermodynamic's entropy.

If there is no rule, then it's definitively random. However, to prove the lack of a rule is pretty difficult, if not impossible as you can't prove a negative. Either way, applying this to the thermodynamic definition of entropy, "free will" is not in the game.

Any comments as to whether we have evidence that quantum mechanics really is /fundamentally/ random?  It seems quite reasonable that if we are observing something that is extremely small and extremely fast, all we will glean from it are statistical summaries.  Yet on its own scale of time and space, maybe it is actually just following some kind of physics?  Like, imagine the position of the Earth around the Sun to someone that experiences a billion years per second.  They'd say "we can guess that the earth is somewhere in this ring  around the Sun, but until we take a measurement, we have no idea where in the ring it is."  Yet - it's on a regular, predictable path, just on an incompatible time scale.  Or the appearance of a kitchen counter to us, that's just the statistical summary of trillions of photon interactions, each of which actually behave predictably.  Just wondering.

Honestly if you took a moment to reflect in the direction things are going in terms of "information", you would realize it's all getting simpler but more complicated at the same time. In the past, a store sign, a logo, adverts, phrases all used throw all the information at you, making it as detailed as possible. But now we're cutting down on all of it. We're optimizing everything around us that conveys messages or has uses to the very best of our ability, which is almost completely opposite of what we did in the past, where we'd describe everything to best of our ability.

A drink ad used to be scripted like "oh my god im so hot, I could really do with someone cool and cold right now", now we just show a bottle of the drink with water going down it to show that it's cold, and putting it on a hot background, making us do all the thinking.

We're going into the tiniest of things, through all that trouble and complications to make the big things simple.

It's remarkable but at the same time, does it have an end or not?

No. Quantum mechanics cannot possibly be a means for free will. The error here is to equate determinism with predictability. Free will means decisions that are not the result of cause and effect, or simply the operation of machinery. Computers are machines. Their results are solely due to cause and effect. All of this operates within a system that is both deterministic and predictable. The universe brings in quantum factors that truly are random (unpredictable). But, they affect our thinking (if they do affect it) as yet another source of causes. That still leaves our brains (thinking machines) subject solely to cause and effect. The difference with a computer is that our thinking is not predictable.

If I drop a watermelon from 100meters in the air.

That is basicially what you call entropy here.

and afterwards, a piece of it is here, a piece there...

but I can still calculate the trajectory of every piece with physics.

It's a fallacy to think quantum mechanics allows for free will.  It's like saying "random things can happen, therefore free will exists."  There is exactly as much credible evidence for the existence of free will as there is for the existence of a specific god:  None.  The only real evidence for free will is that it feels like it exists, which is most likely a survival trait, as brains might survive better if they think they're in control.  Belief in a deity is also based on a feeling that could also be a survival trait.  Free will is a nonsense concept.  It's not even possible to define it without relying completely on preconceived and unprovable notions.  BUT, this is not to say that life is meaningless.  A lot of people reject free will because they think if they accept that it's nonsense, that somehow takes away their humanity and makes them a robot.  This thought process is just as faulty as the one that leads to a belief in free will.

I know I'm going to get in trouble here, but this is B.S., at least partially. It's messing with the definition of "information". If it has no meaning (4:20), then how can you call it "information"? It cannot inform you of anything if it has no meaning. It needs another name, like "un-predictability", or something. Information tells you something new (therefore, you can't predict what it's going to say next), but implicit in that is that it "tells you something".

The place in-between complete order and and complete randomness is where you find "information" (5:02), in the traditional sense of the word and idea. Screwing with the definition of the word can lead you to wrong conclusions (like, in my opinion, calling entropy "information"), and messes with the "information" you are trying to communicate.

Perfect order has no "information", but perfect dis-order also has no "information" (not maximum "information"). It's like a bell-curve, with zero at both ends, and a maximum somewhere in the middle.

This may be a philosophical argument, and not a rigorous scientific one, but calling entropy "information" implies that rational thought does not exist. It's just the sum effect of quantum fluctuations and "events" in our brain, which happen on their own. Analyses and conclusions are not part of a "thought-process"; they are just "what the universe does".

I'd say the contrary, the second law of thermodynamics is far more devastating to the concept of free will than determinism and a predictable future ever have been. Free will is all about agency, controlling what you'll do in the future, but if the subatomic particles are governed by an element of randomness, and everything in the universe is governed by them, then we are fundamentally unable to fully control our future, how could we? It's unpredictable and random. Our decisions then are reduced to just a random outcome of this soup of subatomic probabilities outside of our control. Not only do we not get to control our future, we don't even get to know the 'plan' of our future. Instead, forces outside our control improvise us on the now and we convince ourselves that it was our own decision later.
And if anyone is thinking about the many worlds interpretation to scienfy free will, don't; because you'll condemn yourself even more as you won't have any other option but to be the version of yourself that wasn't realized by the alternate time lines.

I find it hard to understand why the augmentation of entropy is an argument against the (supposed) deterministic nature of the universe.

If we take as an example Conway's Game of Life (which is very clearly of a deterministic nature - after each position n there can only be one n+1 position that follows the rules). We can start from a very easy position (a few cells on the map) and yet it'll grow incredibly complex in a few iterations.
If we wanted to save an intermediate result it might be heavier (i.e require more disk space) to do so than to describe the starting position - and yet the game remains deterministic.

(My supposition is that unpredictably distributed data is not more data than predictably distributed ones. I.e 0001 0001 0001 0001 contains the same amount of information than 1001 1110 1011 0010. The fact that we are able to compress it or store it more intelligently does not mean that information is created when we go from one state to another)

The nature of randomness. (a thought experiment)

A light source was detected in a region near the center of our galaxy that
change polarization (between rhcp and lhcp) in intervals multiple of 1 second
(approx. 1 sec., the multiples are exact). So, coding a 0 for rhcp and 1 for lhcp
in a few years we have registered a sequence of hundreds of millions of 0s and 1s.

All kind of randomness tests and searches for patterns have been made, trying to
figure out the nature of the source of that emission, and we reached the
conclusion that the sequence is completely random. That is, until a month
ago, when a young informatics student in Uruguay compared the recorded sequence
with the binary digits of PI (beginning at digit 4146234112) and found a perfect
match of the more than 200 million registered digits. Now, the digits of that
signal (the polarization of the emitted light) can be predicted much before we
receive them, and the sequence is now considered perfectly deterministic. Many
other similar emissions have been detected, that also pass all randomness tests,
and its "digits" have been compared with the digits of e, of PI beginning in
more "distant" digits, with many other transcendent and non rational numbers and
no correspondence was found yet for any of them, would those other sources be
"really", "fundamentally" random or would they be deterministic as the first
source found??

Do you think that something changed in the nature of the source of the emission
when we discovered that it corresponded to the digits of PI?? Do you think
that the source always was "deterministic" but we didn't know? Do you think
we know what will determine when the source will finish its emission, or the
emission will not correspond anymore to the digits of PI?

The truth is that determinism, randomness, information, probability etc. etc.
are characteristics of a predictive theory (model) that relates the model to
the mind in which the model exist, but are not characteristics to be
correlated with characteristics of the modeled objects and phenomena (like for
instance mass, charge, energy etc.). That is, randomness/determinism are
properties that apply to a model (that exist in a mind), but are categories that
do not apply (have no meaning at all) for anything outside the mind where that
model exist.

Philosophers in the past have defined the Free Will problem in terms of its incompatibility with determinism, but quantum randomness being a proposed solution to the problem seems poorly thought out at best by my estimate. If you replace a truly determined system with a truly random system, then inevitably the individual still has no true control over their actions; they're still being controlled by something far beyond themselves. The only real solution to the free will problem (if there even should be a debate) is to admit that literal, physical free will is a non-starter, but that free will is extremely functional as a psychological concept and is perhaps too hardwired into our evolutionary psyche to even fight against in the first place.

I believe there's a logical fallacy in the way you aimed to reject Laplace's claim. Accepting Laplace does not result in the belief that the amount of information is constant:
Suppose we are Laplace-believers, and we have had the state of the universe at a moment. So everything is predetermined for us, such as the zero-one sequence at 4:02 . For us then, the term used to describe the sequence in the video, namely "random", seems bizarre; "What is he actually meaning by that word?" we would think with ourselves. Thinking of "information" as "randomness" as you mentioned, how could we even assign a meaning to "randomness"? Letting alone to measure the amount of it. Anything that tries to characterize "randomness" like "the amount that we are unsure about something" is meaningless to us. The word "information" would then be meaningless, referring to nothing.

You went like this: Say Laplace was right (therefore there does not exist a meaning to "information"), then remark that the amount of "information" of universe is growing (therefore primarily presumed that "information" bears some notion and so it's meaningful).

So what you are really stating is this: Assume there's no meaning to "information", now to reject this assumption, assume that there's a meaning to "information". Contradiction derived. So Laplace was wrong.

This is not a rejection of that idea by the means you intended.

You aren't doing free will any favors by discounting determinism. Your conscious mind exerts no influence on probability or randomness, but is in fact still the results of processes and laws over which we have no control. If there is not a strict line of causality between each individual event, then your intentions cannot be said to cause your actions. If there is a probabilistic, branching line such as is proposed by the many universe theory, then you still don't control which of those universes you inhabit. Compatabilism is your friend, not your enemy, because the alternatives are far worse for free will and any notion that conscious thought controls action.

Randomness doesn’t have to implicate a free will, as it depends on the definition of a free will. Therefore you could generate the interpretation that due to randomness there is no free will because a free will could be defined as the calculative competence and ability to determine a cognitive result without interference with a forcing dimension. In this case, this dimension would be randomness that determines your cognitive results (thoughts, feelings, activity inducing mental orders,...) to just be random, without any order or choice.
But you could also see randomness as crucial for a free will as it frees nature (as us, too) from determination and guarantees the existence of multiple outcomes with time passing.

And still it is not sure that there actually is an effective influence on our cognitive processes through quantum mechanics due to decoherence.

There is a large (and incorrect) jump of logic made around 5:58

Laplace's Demon is paraphrased by deric as
"Knowing the state of the universe at any one time , also means that you can know the state of the universe at any other time" So far , so good.
but the next thing he states , while showing a graph to cement this idea into the viewers mind is this statement "That would mean that the information in our world would be constant". That second statement does not follow from the first , even if Laplace was right.

Laplace simply said that any state could be known if a single state is completely known, then you could use the single state and all the knowledge you have about it to calculate a future state that would have more (or less) information.

It is possible for determinism to be correct while the entropy of a world still increases.

I have to point out two "weak" spots-or at least that's what they seem to me.
1. The equation of information and entropy, fascinating as it might seem, seems to me possibly shaky. I think this needs to be investigated in various contexts and quantified in order for this hypothesis, if this is the right word, to be valid.

2.Are quantum events random?
Quantum mechanics are, indeed probabilistic in coping with individual events but in large numbers the outcome of quantum events is very highly predictable. The individual events are not predictable and/or deterministic, but their sums are.

So, what kind of hope for new information and/or free will could we base on events that are almost absolutely predictable, when we are talking about very large numbers?

This blithely disregards the fact that the Standard Model of Particle Physics, which is what they refer to with the 12 particles and 4 forces, does not provide a complete picture of the universe. It is perhaps the pinnacle of (mid) 20th century Physics, but decades ago we realised it would not be enough by itself. Dark Matter, Dark Energy, and Quantum Uncertainty throw any deterministic predictions we think we could make with the standard model out the window. The world is weirder than those particles alone, and it might be millennia before we know exactly in what way, to the degree that we could predict even 1 single second into the future.

Okay, as any cryptographer or information theorist could tell Random does not equal Unpredictable. This is why there are "True" random and cryptographically strong random value generators. Even some of the cryptographically strong algorithms are not 100% unpredictable, but they are still random. You can, in fact, mathematically convert a random universe to a deterministic universe and back so random universes are just a special case of a deterministic one. What is unpredictable is 'choice' because it is not mechanical, but semiotic in nature.

This is a little bit off.  The unit of information is the bit.  A bit is the amount of information that resolves two equiprobable outcomes.  You can’t measure the amount of information merely by looking at the values in binary form.  For example, if you know that a memoty is reset to zero, then you read out a string of zeros, there is no information content.  But if you have a bit generator that produces a random zero or one with equal probability, then you read a string of zeros from it, that is information.

8:20 Randomness does NOT pave the way to "free will" or any other type of freedom.
Freedom as a concept is absurd. Conventionally, people like to argue that they are free because they "could have" done this or that. The word "could" is either entirely meaningless or it refers to the hypothesis of parallel universes. So for the sake of the argument, let's subscribe to parallel universes - now there's a version of you out there who acted differently. Great, so what? It would be silly to claim ownership of a random quantum event. By its nature, randomness, you do not control it. It's not your choice to end up in a particular universe. You're a passenger along for a ride with random particle motion.
I've listened to and read many takes on this subject over the years. Not once did I get the impression that I had missed something. Freedom seems to be the deep "god of the gaps" that even atheists cling to. There's really no indication that it exists. It's not needed to explain anything. Yet everybody wants to believe in it.

I don't buy that the existence of random events gives us free will. On a practical level I can't predetermine all non random events or random events, and random events in the past have only happened in one way (let's ignore many world interpretation). But our personal uncertainty about future events makes it seem as though we have free will, if we assume that our perception of reality is rational then I would argue that that is the same as having free will. I therefore believe that free will is possible in a deterministic universe and that the arguments of determinism and free will should be separated.

I don’t know whether that example can carry over into the universe because while patterns can be compressed, in the example of the pixelated screen you could change any pixel and it would not interact with the others at all where as in the universe all particles can interact with other particles in some way otherwise they would not be a particle at all. All particles of mass interact with gravity over an infinitely long distance and ones without mass as least have the potential to interact by some kind of force, meaning that the universe is connected completely whereas a bunch of pixels on a screen are not and are decided by a machine. The universe depends on the interactions of particles completely for anything to happen. When entropy increases there are less patterns leading to more information that cannot be compressed however if you were to break it down into the individual particles there are still the same amount of particles interacting and there are analog differences in for example position that cannot be compressed. For example say there is a big patch of red and blue paint when these paints mix entropy increases as purple is made but no new paint is added and the individual amount of for example paint units stays the same but the 3 larger clumps of paint ordered into red,blue and purple can be arranged to form more colours than before. If we were to look at it as a cluster of two types of particles that can be arranged in a large number of ways in the first place instead on the macroscopic level then the amount of ways that each fundamental particle could arrange would be constant. The increase in information can be attributed not to more particles being added but to less clumping of the particles into similar groups or patterns, there are still the same amount of particles if you were to look at them as individual particles rather than clumps, each interacting just like they would if they were in a more disordered state. Some of what we think as random in quantum mechanics may be due to us not being capable to measuring it properly or due to variables which we have not discovered yet. Information is not data. This video seems to confuse data and information. Information is actually a process, that is best understood as the reduction of uncertainty. There is definitely a link to make between information theory and the idea of complexity and randomness. Randomness is... when the algorithm meant to explain something is just as complex as that thing. Meaning can only be grounded in the mind (not in the symbols, except for numerals, operators, which are computable). All that is contextual. And context only exists as a mental state, in a cognizer's mind...

Without cognizers, there is no information, because there is no uncertainty... In fact, the only way for data to BE informative, is if it reduces uncertainty. This implies that a student who correctly answers a question from a teacher is not informing the teacher, who already knew the answer. It's a mistake to confuse information with mere data. Not all data is informative and information depends on the state of uncertainty of the cognizer. Without cognition, there is no such thing as information. Only meaningless data, with no potential to inform (since that potential depends on the existence of a form of cognition, which might depend on the existence of something capable of being conscious. Remove that and information stops existing... along with meaning...

"Information is entropy"

Okay...have you ever studied information theory. Information is not randomness, but ORDER. Entropy is the loss of order and information. Just because a long code appears random to an ignorant observer, does not make it random to the ones who can read the code. And additional number and letters will only add more information if they have meaning to the one reading the code. If not, they will interfere with the original code and this results in entropy. Entropy does not make a brick wall out of a pile of dirt. It erodes the wall that was built.

This video is correct to suggest that quantum randomness, amplified by chaotic dynamics, is the agent of entropy production. The simplest model of quantum mechanics, inspired by Reinhold Furth, is as a Hamiltonian system with a bit of added Brownian motion. This model outperforms the Schroedinger equation when we are talking about the arrow of time, but underperforms if we are looking for the destructive interference of probability distributions. For a heavy object whose Compton wavelength is less than the Planck length, this doesn't matter. A potential well is a dimple in a heavy object.

A model which does allow the destructive interference of probability distributions is tachyonic Brownian motion which is orthogonal to an oscillation in the other way to travel faster than light. This is one for computer simulation.

I'd add one subtle but profound note about entropy.  Life is a reduction of entropy (*locally).  Although entropy always increases, LOCALLY, life decreases entropy (*Globally increasing).  This is why it's great to live in a universe that is expanding, because it allows us to radiate heat away from us, while at the same time, locally decreasing entropy.  Add this to volition, or the ability to make choices, and you have genuine expression of "choice influenced", non-random, non-predictable, emergent creativity.  Bach instead of white noise, Van Gogh instead of background radiation, and sui generis standing between pure information (random noise) and pure predictability (perfect silence).

I think this video presents a misconception about entropy. The 2nd Law (entropy increases) does not require quantum mechanics to be true. Entropy is just a way of capturing our ignorance to details of a physical system.

We are ignorant of the positions and velocities of the individual air molecules surrounding us, and yet we can still describe the bulk features of the air like how hot it is, how much pressure, etc. The fact is, there are many different microscopic arrangements of the air molecules that would still result in the air looking and feeling exactly like it does now. The number of such arrangements that don't change the overall physical state is the entropy.

Loved the video, but that last phrase... I mean, quantum randomness or any other type of quantum uncertainty and related events in the brain, none of that equates to free will. Free will as a concept is impossible to logically square with reality. It makes no sense by its own claim, if we are material, and our being is governed by material particles and natural laws, and the brain belongs to that set of material, its inner workings, no matter how quantum based and uncertain, is not under control of our "free will", because it is necessarily governed by laws of nature that we may never fully grasp. A belief in an extra metaphysical soul is necessary to believe in free will, and even that, can't be enough, because you didn't choose your soul. And all that is fine, too, btw.

I've clicked on YouTube suggestions with information from the future. For example, there was this video I clicked this morning titled "You sir, are a fish". Hours later, I was looking for something to eat and without even thinking about fish, decided to cook two tilapia and two small salmon slabs. Then, I thought about that video. This has happened before. I watched a video titled "riddle of the rocks". It was one of those super weird, bizarre meme videos. In that video, someone was trying to solve the riddle of the rocks. The answer made no sense. The answer was "lemon"... Anyway, days after I watched that video, I went hiking with my parents and when we reached a waterfall, me and my parents sat down for a while. I noticed these people balancing small rocks on top of each other. There were two small towers of rocks. I was bored so I built my own tower. It was kind of big. When I was done, my mom asked me if I wanted one of her flavored water packets that you put into water and I chose lemon flavor, literally a few seconds later, I remembered that video and was like "hmm" All this happens every now and then. I'm not talking about easy predictions, like an eclipse. People have told me I'm tripping but I showed some people prof that I'm not making this up and they acknowledged that they saw the same thing I saw but never really tripped out on it like I do. They just shrugged it off. I seem to be the only one who thinks this is weird.

Hey sir, LOVE your content!! I have some thoughts that I haven't been able to disprove yet...

Given that

A) Space itself is expanding (dark energy)

B) That entropy is forever increasing, and

C) That anything beyond the observable universe effectively does not exist for us, effectively becoming lost information...

I wonder if there is a symmetry between universal entropy (which is always increasing) and universal availability? (which is always decreasing)

In other words, if we were to assume a universe that has a constant amount of total information available, but that the amount of information per particle was increasing, and the "dark energy" that we've been looking for is really the Universe's way of balancing the scale? What if there is, in fact, a constant amount of total information accessible to our observable Universe?

I'm a software engineer, and one of the hardest parts of my job is getting a big job done within the limits of what a (fast!) modern processor can do. As you no doubt know, without careful thought and design, it's quite easy to write code that will instantly overwhelm a processor with tasks that might take a billion years to complete. Literally can be done with a single line of code that might take longer than projected heat death to accomplish. If you're curious, take a look at the "traveling salesman" problem - a good interview question for a hopeful programmer hire.

So, much of my job consists of deciding what is "good enough" and not computing everything to the "best" answer.

Recently there's been a bevy of people talking about living in a simulation. The increasingly impressive results of highly immersive, graphics-rich video games make it seem more and more possible that we do, in fact, live in such a simulation. And the software engineer in me has been asking: If we do, in fact, live in a simulation of a computer with similar properties to the computers we now have, what would be an indication that this might be so?

The first answer for me is that useless information would have to be thrown away - because that is an enormous and critical part of my job. Isn't that what's happening at the edge of the observable universe? Just a possibility.

What I'd like to know, is if we were to somehow calculate the total amount of entropic "random" information in the observable universe, and compare the rate of entropy increase, subtracting the loss of apparent total information lost at the edge of the observable universe, do we get a total value of accessible information that is constant?

My guess is probably so, but I'd really like to know.

The fact that we cannot predict any events because of increasing entropy doesn't mean we have free will. The notion of free will here is difficult to place in this scientific context. There is always a contradiction within the definition itself. "Free will being defined by quantum effects in our brain" is a strange thing to say because we don't have 'control' over those quantum effects, so how do we have free will.  Of course I believe in all this, but our notion of  'free will' and how we have defined it over the past centuries does not make it possible for us to use it in this context. I'm not saying that we can predict every action led by anyone because the world is deterministic (obviously that's not the case because of thermo) but that doesn't mean that we have free will, or at least the way we have defined it.

Your free will comes from neither the Second Law of Thermodynamics nor random quantum events. It arises from your native ability to focus your neuromuscular feedback control networks on the complex task of sustaining physiological balance over time. Consider an overt act of physiological balance: riding a bicycle. In spite of your top-heavy lack of static stability, you purposefully maintain a dynamic upright posture while perched upon a pair of narrow, rotating wheels. This feat is accomplished not by an unfathomable confluence of quantum events whose cummulative perturbations converge into precisely the trajectory you seem to have had in mind. No, it was achieved by your own force of will, which skillfully fine-tuned your muscular reactions to dynamically compensate and correct innumerable random deviations from your intended course. Had your excursion been steered by nothing more than the permutations of an incalculable sequence of events predetermined by an inscrutable configuration of initial conditions, the Planckian precision required to produce exactly that outcome would have millenia ago dissolved beneath an ocean of quantum foam.

Entropy in our universe isn't going up. If one think otherwise then he doesn't understand the entropy nor the time as an dimension.
Time is a dimension.
If I have a glass, and I drop in on the floor causing the glad to breakfast and fall apart, then the number of atoms belonging to that glass hasn't changed. Their order and location has changed, but that didn't caused an increase of entropy. Glass had just traveled in time, or to be more precise: information that was enclosed in that glass, has traveled through time. The amount of information hasn't changed. It's only our human weakness, that what we could describe as one glass, now we have to describe as glass pieces scattered on the floor. The amount of information about that glass hasn't changed. Every molecule of that glass still has its own bit of information like where it is, what's it's temperature etc.
Saying that entropy in the universe is increasing is stupid.

Two things: Laplace's demon would still not know the future because randomness is not to be confused with unmeasurability but actually means unknowable. Radioactive decay is truly random and not because we cannot measure all properties of an atom. Therefore we could create a lottery which determines the jackpot ticket using the nanoseconds since 1970 at time of the decay. Depending who wins the ticket, this event could alter history, but Laplace's demon still would not know who wins the ticket.
The other thing: random influences in or on our brain do not constitute free will, but rather the opposite. They may make our thinking unpredictable but this, in my mind, does not constitute free will.

Answer: Causality.

A few thoughts which seem to join with the others here in bringing us all to the verge of some big breakthrough:
------

First, in what we conceptualize as [- how we 'cartoonize' the infinite complexity of reality into -] our reality "composed of" "separate events",
re the aspect of "those events themselves", with or without any observer:

{As Derek & Michael so clearly & kindly point out:}
The more information in any "event", then
the more randomness [or disorder] in it.

Yet, as for living "patterns" (& the "patterns" of "things" surrounding "them"),
"they" "exist" only near some particular proportion ( +/- the magical 'fractal ratio' ) of order to disorder.

So, for life to happen requires, locally to each "being", not only partial disorder {- yes -} , but also for local information to be only partially maximized.

--------

Somewhat related to that:

It is often said that many "processes", especially 'alive' "ones", actually are producers of - yes - orderliness .

(E.g.: Think of water crystallizing into more orderliness, whether as snowflakes, or as 'ice-ferns' [flat crystalline fern-like patterns] on the surface of a frozen pond.
Or, think of a tiny seed sprouting, or a newborn animal, comprising what seems obviously to be yet more orderliness coming into existence than before.
)

So, could it be that, actually, entropy (the ambient ratio of disorderliness to orderliness) doesn't actually always increase, but rather is yet another property (along w/ motion, energy, & some symmetries) that actually is eventually perfectly conserved, thru-out all space & time?

If so, then, is Laplace's hypothesized ever-more-deducing observer possible, after all ?

(-- well, it would be able to deduce everything only if, for one thing, it were immortal. But many do testify [from e.g. NDE's] that mountains of evidence indicate that, actually, we all -- all our "consciousness-streams", anyway -- are immortal .
)

.. .. ..

{ Plz help clarify yet more re this; thanks. }

-----------

So at-least hopefully all this above helps clarify a bit more re one of the two main connotations of the word 'randomness': that of its being used to describe how orderly or disorderly that "sub-events" are actually happening within one or more larger "events", whether "they" are being observed or not.

-----------

Then, re the other connotation, of the word being used to describe how orderly or disorderly that "events" appear [to an observer] to be happening:

FWIW: For Laplace's mythical "totally-astute observer" to be able to deduce,
from merely knowing ever more re an infinity of infinitesimal "sub-events" composing some "event", no matter how small, no matter where,
[to deduce] ever more re all the "sub-events" comprising ever more other "events" all around that first small "event",
& then, same re all "events" around those "events",
& then, same re . . . .
for this, it is required that, for one thing, all "events" everywhere to be -- as actually all proper experiments do indeed prove "them" to be -- perfectly 'conserved' [or 'inter-accountable'] with "each other".

--- FWIW.

{ Plz help clarify yet more re this; thanks. }

---------

Note, BTW, that this complete Conservation that we observe all around us seems to go beyond mere 'Godelian' consistency
[ 'Godelian' = reliable~true but only as far as it extends ] ;
it seems to entail that every single "event" is actually either participating in completely determining, or in being completely determined by .. (, even if via zero or more intervening "events" -- OK, always, always_, via an _infinity of infinitesimal "ones", ) .. completely determined by (& completely deducible by knowledge of) every single other "event" (- by all of "them" together -), thru all "space", thru all preceding "time".

& So, one corollary of the existence of our universal Conservation is that, indeed, the more one knows re just one "event" anywhere -- i.e., re all its "sub-events" -- then, the more one can deduce re all other surrounding "events" (& their "sub-events") in turn . .
& then re yet "others" all around "them" . .
& then re yet still "others" . . . . . .
etc.

I.e.: It's starting to seem as if the fact of perfect Conservation (of motion etc) might imply the possibility of .. yes each "one" of us becoming ever more 'enlightened' or 'awakened' re "each other" & re "every thing" around us.

{!}


--------

Now, for perhaps the most provocative issue for most of us, in all of this:

Given that
The apparent "randomness", on quantum scales [very very tiny orders of magnitude] relative to us,
is actually merely a result of the fact that we, relative 'mega-observers', & our 'mega-particle beams' or whatever we use to observe, are so very much bigger than what we're trying to observe down in those quantum scales;

and so, our beam's mega-particles are violently knocking around those tiny "events", into a state that appears, once we deduce from observing our beam's resultant scatterings, to be a good deal of "randomness" 'down there';

i.e., given that universal Conservation means that actually any apparent "randomness", at least in the outcomes of "events", is merely an illusory artefact of our attempts to observe "them", and nothing more;

then,
with no randomness actually, in the outcomes of "events" anywhere, doesn't that mean that our so-treasured "freedom" in our own choices is actually . . merely illusory?

--- apparently, yes.


However, since obviously most of us tend to feel better, & usually to do better in life, the more that we believe ourselves to be acting "freely" . .

(---- as well as feeling better, & usually doing better in life, by believing ourselves to each be a "separate person", surrounded by "separate things~events" [-- also actually all "separateness" being an illusion, altho one so convened-upon by us that any communication, & any stepwise co-sciencing {such as this dialog}, requires it --] ;

as well as feeling better, & usually doing better in life, by, for most of us, believing that there is some "uber-patriarch", some "omniscient all-benevolent God", always watching over, protecting, & guiding us all;

as well as feeling better, & usually doing better in life, whenever one can believe that one has a "home", &/or belongs to a certain "community", & even a certain "nation" .. .. ..

as well as feeling .. ..

.. .. etc

----)

>>> Conservation (of motion, energy, symmetry, space-time, etc) <<< .

[ --- "Conservation" =: "Dynamic Balance" ~ "Inter-accountability" ~ "Inter-relatedness" ~ "Cause-and-Effect" ~ "Causality" ~ .. & even, "all rebalancings everywhere, however far-reaching (-- observable ones being only those very-rare much-closer & much-quicker ones --) that we call 'Karma' " ] .

Both our own everyday perceptions & all proper experiments upon macro-scale phenomena [ 'macro' = near our own size ] always show that this Conservation, for those aspects in which it is consistently shown to hold, is apparently universal , without even one proven exception anywhere, ever, at-least in the outcomes from, if not the inputs to, all events on our same 'macro' scale.


From this consistency in all such macro-scale observations, easily showing all macro-scale events around us to obey this Conservation (rather than to be random) at least in their outcomes,

any apparent but illusory "randomness" in any of such quantum-scale [very tiny] events (at-least in their outcomes) must all be attributed to some issue with some extraneous factor(s), rather than to their own tiny processes themselves;

thus, focusing on the extraneous factor of our mere observation of such very tiny events, if we consider some nearly-parallel situation, such as the hypothetical one of some mega-mega-huge alien entity trying to observe us, whose proportion of size to us is about the same as that of us to atoms, this mega-entity might perhaps try to observe us by using, say, a beam of its scale's "particles" which were tiny on its scale but still just huge in our scale, and thus which would knock us around violently while the mega-entity was monitoring its beam's resultant scattering, as some way to "observe" us; then, would we be surprised if it concluded that, on our scale, everything appeared to be helter-skelter, indeed "random"?
(No.)

And so, that seems to be why, on the quantum scale relative to us, such tiny events appear to us (relatively, mega-entities) to be "random", even tho their aggregate behavior (as macro-scale events) always shows actually perfect Conservation (at-least in each event's outcome, if not in each one's inputs.)

Determinism and predictability are so often conflated, because we don't have access to actual reality, without mediation of our senses and cognition. This conflation leads to so many erroneous paradoxical conclusion such as "Entropy = Information". A "random" arrangement of bits only constitutes "information" in RELATION to a sequence of zeros. So it is the ORDER in that uniformity of zeroes that GIVES the apparently-random distribution of 1s it's INFORMATION. It's only when the entropy is considered as a set of deltas/differences from a perfectly-ordered arrangement that it gains the consideration of representing information. And even then, only through a particular interpretive framework. The exact same arrangement of bits can be both noise and signal at the same time, when read via different interpretive-structures - structures that are very much NOT random.

I think your definition of information here might be what's confusing me. A set of only zeros has as much information as a random set of zeros and ones. This is because unless you tell me what number comes after each zero on the first example, I have no way of knowing, and therefore each zero is information. Now of course you can compress this into just, zero. But you were only able to compress this when you were informed of the contents of that file. You had to use each bit of information on that file, before you created a new file, that was less repetitive. So it doesn't seem right to deny all these extras are, too, information.

6:15 "That would mean entropy is also constant, and that does not appear to be the universe we live in." It doesn't? 8:29 "For us to really have free will we need the 2nd law of thermodynamics." Honestly, I think that's wishful thinking. Rising entropy does not mean the universe is not deterministic. It just means It's much harder to predict it. It's still deterministic, and therefore still hypothetically predictable, along with all of human behavior, past present and future. So I still agree with Mr. Laplace.

However, a deterministic universe does not necessarily mean an absence of free will. You act according to your will. It's just that your will is predetermined, and this is fine, because it doesn't go against your will. Your will cannot go against itself. Yes, even when you're on a diet craving that chocolate cake. You still end up making a decision, and thus exercising your will.

Can one understand, explain and predict a certain outcome of happening? As i stated before, you could actually measure "randomness", but to explain why something happens exactly the way it happens, would be more difficult, if not completely impossible. Independently of a outcome distribution type being more random or less random, it would not be expected that a human being could actually understand, explain and predict a certain outcome type or a certain sequence of happening. We as human beings are limited in our capabilities, intelligence, comprehension, etc. Possible outcome distribution types or sequences are influenced and conditioned by an almost infinite group of factors and variables. To fully understand why something behaves the way it does, one would have to simultaneously embrace and dominate all these variables. If a outcome type is truly random to it's fullest extent than we would have to admit that there are no variables or external factors that are influencing and restricting the outcomes. That is why true "randomness" is a theoretical concept, because in a real physical world/scenario it would be incomprehensive that a generation of outcomes wouldn't have any conditional or influential elements.

Can we measure "randomness"? If we consider the premise that true "randomness" exists to it's fullest extent when all the possible outcomes have EXACTLY the same probability of happening and acknowledge that "randomness" is a relative concept, then it is theoretically and mathematically possible to measure "randomness". The only way to achieve this is by conducting a massive amount of events/trials/experiments (the bigger the number the more precise are our conclusions). In order to measure "randomness", the specific outcome sequence would not be relevant by itself, since any sequence has the exact probability of happening (although this would be difficult for most people to understand ). The truth is that, only through the analysis of the distribution type of the outcome frequencies that a certain sequence belongs to, are we able to, effectively, measure "randomness".

that bit about QM been probabilistic is an big argumentative trap. There are deterministic models for QM, that predict everything that the non-deterministic do. So actually, for all we know, QM may not be probabilistic at all (and with that, the reality may be deterministic, if you're basing your argument on classical QM), you just learn it this way in undergrad courses (that's called Copehagen interpretation).
That's also probably why Einstein said that " God doesn't play dice, because there were many other (equally good) QM theories in his time, and none was standard. Of course, there are chaotic Quantum systems, but that's another story.
If you're curious look for Bohmian Mechanics and Many-world theory (or QM done by Everett).

Is there anything truly random? In nature and in the universe, probably. If it's man made or man created most probably not. Before u analyze anything it starts of by being uncertain (not the same meaning of random). After analyzing something it could prove itself being more or less random. I'm using the words more ore less because randomness is a relative concept. It is wrong to say that something is random or not random. One could say that something is more or less random. In the same way it is relative and even subjective to say that there is a pattern. What could we consider a pattern? A pattern could be something for a person and something else for another person. Actually true randomness does follow a more likely pattern regarding it's distribution type. And when I mean distribution type I'm not talking about the distribution type that they teach you at school and throughout the internet, I'm talking about a abstract distribution type where the actual specific frequencies of each outcome is not relevant . This more likely pattern in the distribution outcome may occur if one could replicate true randomness. But since that would be almost impossible, the distribution types tend to present themselves more convergent because we can't assure that all the possible outcomes have exactly the same probability of happening. So presuming that certain outcomes have a higher probability of happening than others, so does certain outcome sequences , so does certain outcome distributions and so does certain outcome distribution types. What most people call patterns are simply the result of all of the possible outcomes not having the exact same probability of happening.

Before I even watch this video, I'll answer the title's question:

Pattern.

Randomness and pattern are antithetical; mutually exclusive. This comes up in my arguments with atheists all the time. I had one screech at me, "WHY CAN'T IT ALL JUST BE RANDOM!?" Well, for starters, you couldn't even begin to ask that question without the existence of patterns. It (the Universe) very well may have started out in randomness, but the instant patterns emerge, randomness dies, because they cannot coexist in the same place. Besides, even randomness can only exist according to the pattern that determines it to be what it is. Randomness has a definition, a meaning, and that itself is a pattern. It must be "made, done, happening, or chosen without method or conscious decision," and that itself is a pattern used to describe what is to be considered "random". This is much the same way that deception can only be deception in accordance with Truth; it must be True that it is deception or it cannot be considered deception. It must be Correct that incorrectness is incorrectness, or it cannot be incorrectness.

Randomness cannot exist without pattern; it ONLY exists because of pattern.

Bonus info:
The word "pattern" has its etymological roots in the Greek word "pater" which means "father".
The word "matter" likewise comes from the Greek word "mater" which means "mother".
The word "matrix" is essentially "womb".

I just want to talk a little about the entropy part.

Entropy is typically referring to heat required to raise the temperature of a substance. This is a very concrete definition. What I have more trouble understanding is the second definition of entropy as "disorder". What exactly counts as disorder? Is there a precise way to measure it, because if not, then we can't just say something is more disordered just because it "looks disordered".

Imagine this:

I have a piece of fabric. If I were to flatten it and try to stand it on its edge, it would instantly collapse into a messy pile. I might observe that the fabric went from a "compressible state" into a more chaotic state. However, was that really the case?

If we were to take a look at the fabric on a microscopic level, there are atoms distributed everywhere. No equation can accurately define a set of particles, even though I might say the atoms lie on the XZ plane, they really aren't. I need to describe every single atom individually.

Now, hypothetically, IF the atoms were to lie perfectly on the XZ plane, with all the quarks perfectly balanced, then we might indeed say the trillions of particles can be represented by a single, simple equation. However, what will happen is, since it is perfectly balanced, the cloth will not move at all. If it were to move, it must be due to an outside force, and the entropy would have simply be gained from that outside force.

I may be completely wrong, but I guess my main question is: is there any proof that the entropy in the universe is indeed increasing, and how can we precisely measure entropy in a systematic way?

Just because the nature of our universe is fundamentally probabilistic, it does not mean that we have free will. If you take the metaphor that the equations governing a deterministic universe are like a puppet master controlling a puppet (us), then the puppet does not have free will, as it's being controlled by something else. In a probabilistic universe, the puppet master may decide what the puppet does through rolling a dice (or some other method that is truly random) but fundamentally he is still controlling the puppet. Hence we do not have free will just because the universe is probabilistic as opposed to deterministic.

The idea that a perfectly compressed video (any data) is also perfectly entropic appears true, but it only contains information if we consider something external to it: the algorithm to decode, which is fundamentally non-entropic information. We can only regard this as a whole system, i.e. entropic pattern + decoding algorithm, lock + key. So your statement that humans operate mainly on mid-entropic data is not only trivially true like you present, but this set also includes such lock + key composite constructs.
I am also a fan of the quantum effects in the brain => free will view (I reject the view we are all deterministic robots with all my heart and mind). But I think we know too little about the mystery of consciousness and qualia to discount a non-"physical" (meaning presently known physics, not supernatural souls) substance that enables interactions past the tight bounds of traditional physics. For example, I am very open to the view that reality (or particles) fundamentally contains a mind-like aspect that is just as (or more so) real than traditional physics. Such a mechanism where mind is embedded in the fabric of reality, able to influence it, would solve the free will question elegantly.

Seems legit. But is it?

① * Does information = entropy?
The whole idea of video compression is cutting out information to achieve smaller file size. Every video frame has the same number of pixels and every pixel has its characteristics. Video compression removes those that are deemed less important for the spectator. However, then this compressed video is displayed, it again contains the same number of information (assuming the same resolution) but not the same information as the original information has been lost in the compression process.

② * Random (noisy) information.
It is difficult to compress because it has low number of adjacent bits that could be categorised by compression algorithm into a "similar enough" bucket described by single piece on information. However, it doesn't matter if the information is noisy or completely uniform - it still contains the same "maximum" amount of bits or pixels, and every pixel has its own property - meaning the actual amount of information is the same. The difference is only the susceptibility to compression. But nature doesn't do compression - it runs on "RAW".

And again - even lossless compression does not contain the original information. It only contains new information which allow reconstruction of original data. And guess what happens when this is recreated... It is the same "size" as the original!
So compressed information ≠ original information.


Thus it does not follow, that information equals entropy.

③ * Entropy vs order.
The previewed order or disorder is a human concept. It is a way we name things arranged in particular way - not an intrinsic property of the universe.
The number of things (hence the information) is the same no matter how are they arranged. For example, no matter if your ex threw all your clothes on the floor of your room out of the closets, or the clothes are nicely folded up in the closets - you still have the same amount of clothes in the room.

④ * Quantum unpredictability.
We cannot predict where the electron will be at some later time. But is it because it is in fact random/undetermined, or is there an unknown process that actually determines it? And how would you know the difference? You wouldn't.

So why go for "random" rather than "unknown" if each time we gained enough knowledge about some subject, everything which seemed random turned out to be determined? Solar eclipses is a simple example.
Remember - probability is only a quantification of our lack of knowledge - a human concept, not an actual thing.

⑤ * Free will.
Regardless whether the future is determined or "random", it has no bearing on lack of our "free will" as it is commonly understood. By this point it is pretty well established we as conscious beings are merely perceivers and executors of the "decisions" of our brains, not the actual decision-makers. Even if the conclusion of this video was correct, the future of such undetermined world would be result of random physical processes, not our conscious choices. Free will is dead either way.

In the end, you can't even decide which side convinces you more. But you certainly can contemplate it.
