We build quantum computers by getting close to 0 kelvin around the quantum bits so that the calculations of the computer are based almost purely on the quantum particles and no other effects near it.

What if our will also exists and can have an impact on certain things, but the impact is so small that most particles don't care about what your will is doing.
What if our brains are also just devices that measure our very small and almost impactless "free will" to make decisions based on them and thus make our will have great impact on our body and through the body on the rest of the world.
That would also support the theory that we have some kind of soul and if our soul is detached from our brain (for example when teleporting or being in a coma) our brains wouldn't be able to measure our will anymore and would stop any activity that was based on our will and only keep doing whatever was independent of our will all the time. For example pumping blood is independent of our will, we can't directly affect it with our will, because our brain always pumps blood based on other things it measures like our body temperature and never changes our blood pressure based on our will. So even when someone is in coma his blood will keep pumping because it was independent of our will in the first place.

Sure we can affect our blood pressure indirectly by using our will to exercise, but that isn't the same thing.

When a baby is born and starts learning how to move the body the will is just doing random things and once the brain reacts to the will by moving a body part the will recognizes that by doing that random thing the brain will always move that body part.

Since no human brain is exactly the same some people have more control over their body than others.

If your brain happens to move some muscles inside your body in a specific way based on the input it gets from your will to make a specific sound someone else's brain might not care about the input from the will when deciding whether to move that muscle or not.

With this in mind, swapping peoples consciousness might be possible at some point.
Since the brain and the will are probably seperatable from each other we might be able to insert someone's will into someone else's brain.
The parts of the brain that manage important body functions would work the same since the brain didn't change, but the random input from the will would be different.

Also, when you're sleeping it's not your brain that is actually sleeping but your will since you are making less conscious thoughts while sleeping and your brain is just autopiloting through your memory and imagining situations by mixing memories together without caring about the random input from your will.
Lucid dreaming is just your will waking up and interrupting whatever your brain is doing but without interrupting it too much because that would result in your brain stopping the memory mixing and starting to move your body parts again based on the will instead of using your will's input for memory mixing.

In other words, your brain is a closed computer program that doesn't let anyone access the code and always does specific processes in the background and relies on user input for other processes.

Being awake is like playing a video game. You can control the main character with your input but your possibilities are very limited. You can't tell the game to make your character vomit. The game just wont doesn't care about your input when deciding whether your character should vomit. You can tell the character to eat something spicy which might in turn lead to the character vomiting but it's all limited by what the game wants to allow you to control and what not.
Sleeping is like watching a video in full screen. Most people just let the video pass by and if they suddenly start giving the computer input, for example by pressing some buttons on the keyboard, the video might leave full screen or just stop playing altogether which would make you wake up. Lucid dreaming is when you give input to the computer without interrupting the video. If you click space bar the video will pause. This is what most people would press first. But if you're a lucid dreamer you know what buttons to press to influence what you can see (or imagine) without closing or pausing the video (waking up).

Swapping consciousnesses of two people would be like two users changing computers. Your friends computer will probably react to your input very similarly as your computer. Most computers will exit full screen if the user presses ESC. Some computers might be programmed to exit full screen when the user presses space though. Not only may computers and brains be programmed to handle some input differently, but some computers might even allow you to do some things that your computer doesn't. Like SYNCHRONIZING RGB EFFECTS. Going back to your own computer you can input the exact same as you did on your friends computer, your computer just wont synchronize RGB effects because it doesn't care about your input for that process or just isn't even capable of doing that.

Also giving birth would be like using two computers' parts to build a new computer and cloning would be like picking a specific build and deciding to build an exact copy of it. Or to produce many copies of it serially to sell them to some school.

An information stream that has been stripped of all redundancy most certainly is not “random”! It could be said to be “unpredictable.” That, in the specific sense that you can’t use redundancy to predict its content.

However, that exactly does not make it random and thus information-free! In fact, that makes it exactly the opposite: information-dense!

Using your example, a highly-compressed video-data stream looks very unpredictable if you view it as just a stream of bits, but it’s very clearly not random because when interpreted correct, it produces a very-informational video stream!

I fear I disagree in some points:
First, I disagree with your definition or your usage of 'Information'.

How I see it and how the Word is usually used, information cannot be uncoupled from meaning.
A list of 0s and 1s does not convey information, only if those Numbers have a meaning does it make sense to talk about information.

And in that Sense the order or simplicity is irrelevant to the amount of information conveyed.

Lets assume those numbers are measurements of Quantum States of particles, lets say the spin. 0 is down, 1 is up. Then a List consisting of only 0s tells us just as much as a completely random and unpredictable result, the amount of information is the same, even if you can compress it. Order only reduces Information if it is not a result of the information. For example if we only have 3 particles that we measure and then arbitrarily say that when we send this information we just infinitely repeat those three datapoints, then the ability to compress the data actually means that there is less data, because there is no additional meaning.
So information is meaning which is also why we value this Word 'information' at all.

Defining Information as randomness robs it of its value, why would anyone care about randomness its absolutely not important, except maybe for a free will debate where randomness actually comes from. (I know you didnt just define it as randomness, but its what you ended up with, and even if the intuitional meaning of 'Information' would be randomness then that word would also be useless)



Second of all, Enthropy is not randomness, its disorder.

Even if we accept your definition of Information they are not the same.
This becomes very clear when we know that the second law of thermodynamics would still be a thing even if quantum mechanics didnt exist, in other words: even in a Universe with no randomness in it whatsoever (Also known as a deterministic universe) Entrophie would still increase. Quantum mechanics has nothing to do with this.



Thirdly: There is still no free will. If your actions are based on truly random events that you have absolutely no control over than you still have no free will. I frankly couldnt even think of what kinds of physics would be needed to actually allow free will.



Arguing that if everything else is theoretically computable, that only information from those truly random quantum events is the only new information in our world i could agree with, it depends wether or not one would convey new meaning as information only if the person that recives the information doesnt know about it even if he could know it in theory.


In conclusion my critique of this video would be that it seems to me that you used some wrong definitions that lead to a wrong conclusion.
If i missunderstood or you disagree im open for corrections and debatte, please correct me if i am mistaken.

Short answer: Random doesn't exist. Everything is consequential and have reason.

Random - is what we call something, like a result, that we aren't going to calculate. Whether it's because we don't have the means to do it or any other reason. Nothing is random. We call things random for the same reason we say 'I don't know'. Random is something you don't know how to predict. Even when flipping a coin, the result could be calculated through environmental knowledge, forces and bodies that interreact. Like how much force you put in what specific muscle of your hand. How much your finger accelerates vs friction force. Gravity. Angle of, well, everything. Do you move your hand in any way after you catapult the coin, which can influence the number of flips in mid air. Does the angle at which it lands on your hand is enough to stop, or will it friction through for an extra final flip to the other side. So, so many factors, that are objectively absolutely calculatable, but we just don't do it. Nothing is ever random. Not chaos, not entropy, nothing.

The only things that aren't random, are the ones we will correctly predict through calculation

"What is information?"

How should we approach a question like that -- a "what is" question?

What is a cat? It is an animal that meows. So we first name a larger category, then we distinguish our target from all other members of that larger category. So information is a ... I don't know of a larger category of thing that includes information.

What is a pair of pliers? It is a tool (see what I did there?) that squeezes things. Okay, we can approach our "what is" question by saying what you can do with the thing once you've got it. Then information is something that you can use to make distinctions, to distinguish one thing from another, to say "yes" to one and "no" to another.
And yet the digits of pi are said to be random (except that they aren't of course) -- so what does randomness have to do with past vs. future?

As an analogy, let's say we create or/and play a video-game. The dev-code of the video game, is the deterministic aspect of the game, as designed by us. The chaotic element, is how we then play with and change it, as players and developers. In that sense, no matter if we know all that is within the "verse" of the video game in its current state, if we feel like makin' something new, there's gonna be something new. So, if an "universal intelligence" knew everything within any particular version of the game, but not beyond it, it's "omniscience" would be limited to the game-world, and would be oblivious of both other iterations of the game, and us as the creators and players of the game.

Likewise with "reality" and spirit. I/We, as spirit and consciousness, create "realities" in which we then roleplay as the characters of our choosing. However, sometimes we choose that, on an in-character level, we might not always be aware of this, hence the illusion of identifying with the experience.

Chaos is not a result of "not knowing" something. That's just nescience. Chaos is also not "entropy". Entropy is an illusion, born when people don't know where "stuff goes" after they "decay", dissolve or vaporize.

Chaos is the random aspect of infinite potential. Order is the structured aspect of infinite potential. Order without chaos is rigid and restrictive. Chaos without order is aimless and random. To have harmony, one needs to acknowledge and express both aspects. When combining the curiosity, playfulness, vastness of chaos, with the decisiveness, analysis and structure of order, then we create beautiful stuff.

In a sense, chaos and order are not mutually exclusive or contradictory, but rather go very well hand in hand. Both have negative and positive aspects to them, and the point is to discern the good from the bad, and decide what we want to experience. Everything is spirit and expressions of ourselves as s[orot, infinite and unlimited consciousness, potential, being and veyond... among other things...

a math teacher I once had said if N equals the sides of a regular polygon, N=infinity is the point at which you have a circle. Because the greater the N the more round the shape becomes. There are fundamental problems with this video:
-2nd law of thermodynamics doesn't need of QM to be true, e.g. take a bunch of electrical equally charged classical particles and put them in one corner of a box (something that we will consider a ordered state of low entropy). Then, if we let the system evolve the particles due to electrical repulsion will evolve into a disordered state (high entropy) in which the particles are distributed all over the box. The second law of thermodynamics is just a consequence of our concept of order (states with low probability or low number of "microstates" compatible with the state) and that physical laws (quantum or classical) do not care about such order.
-Apart from some weird Penrose conjectures there are no evidences that quantum events affect the brain in a meaningful way apart from that chemistry is derived from QM. Nonetheless, most current models of the brain would work with a classical theory in the background. We don't need QM to explain animal behavior and Neural Networks.

Although the first part of the video is a nice introduction to Information Theory, the second part is full of pseudoscientific conjectures and missinformation.

I know this is kind of old, but somehow while watching both of your channels I missed this.
You mention the butterfly effect as something that makes things unknowable, but the whole point of chaos theory is that even in what seems to be unknowable chaotic systems there is actually order. That if you simply knew enough information you could accurately predict what it will do. Are whole weather system is based on chaos theory. We know where the jet streams are, where the mountains are, how hot it is, where the oceans are, how close we are to the sun. Every single condition we can see and test helps us understand what something will do with greater accuracy, Chaos theory does not say things are random, it says they only appear to be random because you don't have enough information, and assuming that things are random simply because you cannot observe everything ourselves to prove it is an argument from ignorance. You also mentioned how new information is being generated and this new information is why we cannot predict what will happen, which would make sense how could we predict something completely new? However, this goes against another law of thermodynamics, the first law. Matter and Energy cannot be created or destroyed in a isolated system, you can only change their form. Isn't it kind of a stretch to assume that new information is being generated simply because we cannot see where it is coming from? Why assume something so drastic as the first law of thermodynamics is being violated? Why assume things are random, when we are finite and unable to see, nor comprehend, everything?

The second law of thermodynamics is pretty interesting; It's simply that as things progress they become more and more chaotic and unpredictable.

For example: When you put an ice cube into a liquid it begins as a solid and the ice and liquid are two separate things, easy to observe and measure. As the ice melts it mixes in with the liquid and the two become much more difficult to differentiate. This applies to the whole of life in that immediately after the creation of the universe things were very "solid", separate and organized and as they expanded and melted together they became more jumbled and harder to organize.

I think it's interesting to consider the whole melting ice thing since even though these two simple things become far more disorganized and even nearly impossible to identify, they remain fundamentally the same two simple compounds.

After all the FIRST law of thermodynamics is that energy cannot be created or destroyed.

The second law of thermodynamics has nothing to do with the randomness of quantum observations. It is a concept of statistical mechanics that arises even in the treatment of completely classical systems following Newtonian physics. It describes the fact that an observer starting out with non-perfect information about a system can't have his uncertainty about the system's state decrease as it evolves with time. The uncertainty (entropy) can only increase or stay the same.

You should find this in almost any textbook on statistical physics.

The uncertainty of quantum mechanics also does not seem related to the concept of human "free will" in the slightest.
Think about it for a second. If free will somehow manifested as the ability of human observers to choose the outcomes of quantum observations, that would mean these observations wouldn't be random any more. They would statistically correlate with the desires of the observers/the states of their brains.
There is no evidence of anything like this happening in any quantum experiment ever.

You’re confusing entropy with information in the context of particles of the universe. Just because there’s an increase in entropy, it doesn’t mean there’s a necessary increase in information. Maybe it's the concept of free will itself that just doesn't make sense. Maybe the notion of free will is simply not a self consistent thing? I mean when I think of free will, I think of the notion that I am somehow a separate entity from the rest of the universe, self-contained and able to make decisions about things without interference from the outside world. So for a decision to be truly voluntary, a true example of free will being excercised, it would have to be completely unaffected by the outside world - but that is a paradox, because you can't make decisions about anything without receiving information, and thus interacting with the universe, so the whole concept just breaks down. Unless you allow for interference from the outside world, but then - are you truly free? or were your actions really determined (pun intended) by your surroundings, things outside of your control? It seems bizarre to think that we can have free will because it implies that there is an individual there to have it. But there isn't, because everything that makes us, "us" was determined by other (perhaps random) events that we had no control over, exactly because the transient thing that we think of as "ourselves" is perpetually being shaped by our surroundings, and has been for as long as we have existed, and will for as long as we exist. It's really trippy to think about these kinds of things. It seems like the inevitable concusion is that free will is an empty and meaningless concept, and that the notion of an individual identity, a self, is just as absurd, since the two are inextricably linked to one another - and then you just think "great but wtf do I do with that?" and you go on as if nothing has changed.

A bit late to this, but I think it's not quite correct to say "information = entropy." In information theory, entropy is the accumulation of uncertainty after preforming a series of measurements that give you information. The reason the string "0000000000" has less entropy than "1001010110" is because you have less uncertainty in the former case as to what the next value of the sequence is. That also means "0000000000000000000000000000000000" is even lower entropy than "0000000000" since you have a stronger prior (and less uncertainty) in what the next value will be. But which of these two sequences is more informative? The former, since it gives you greater predictability for the next term in the sequence. So the relationship between information and entropy is not an equality. I think saying that white noise contains "maximum information" is not a meaningful thing. Neither is saying that a blank screen contains no information at all. In theoretical terms, you have it flipped.


In some sense, information in the way that you are talking about is a measure of bipartite entropy, in which partitioning a string into subsystems (e.g. "001001100100" into "001001" and "100100") allows them to be compared in a simpler way (in this case realizing that the two strings are related by a single operator that reverses them). This can also be a sort of "course-grained" entropy, in which predictability of the next part of a sequence is low, but predictability of the next 10 parts of a sequence is high (for instance, knowing that 6 of the next 10 are likely to be 0's, but having no information about their order). Strictly speaking, this is not the same thing as Shannon entropy.

As someone who has studied information theory, you got most it right, but left out some important things. Shannon's information isn't the only information.

Informational entropy isn't the same as thermodynamic entropy. Thermodynamic entropy is randomness. Information entropy is negative thermodynamic entropy(as far as the equations are concerned). Meaning that information entropy is the opposite of randomness. Also, thermodynamic entropy characterises a state, one point in it's phase space, if you picture it as a graph. Shannon's entropy however characterises a source of information, not the information itself. So Shannon's entropy is a path or a curve, running through it's phase space.

The second law of thermodynamics isn't a law actually. It contradicts with Newton's second law. It's actually a mathematical approximation, meaning that isn't true everywhere. It has to do with how the law is modelled. It deals primarily with gases, where the molecules are modelled as spheres and not as what they actually are. Entropy isn't actually universally increasing, because gravity. The universe is becoming more ordered. Entropy is increasing in relation to information, which is order. Thermodynamic entropy is also increasing, but in that case it means disorder. So these entropies are not the same thing.

You've got it all wrong. There's nothing random in quantum mechanics formulation, only in its interpretation and the born law. The multiverse interpretation doesn't leave anything random, and knowing the full state of the wave function at any point you can know the rest of it in the future. Quantum mechanics is actually inconsistent with any information gain because the evolution is unitary. Implying that at any point the information increases means non-unitary evolution.


Your notion of entropy is also misleading. A better way to describe entropy, is how many micro-states (ways to describe something in detail) result in the same macro-state. For the best example of why this notion is wrong and confusing, consider a mixture of oil and water, which will separate into seemingly more-ordered state after a while.

My understanding has it that Entropy has nothing directly to do with order, disorder or randomness. Entropy is stricly a measure of how spread out energy is within a frame of reference. Order and disorder are subjective, one person's order can be another's disordered. You can't say just because something looks more random or disordered than it was before that is has more Entropy. In general, an increase in Entropy can give rise to an increased perception of disorder but this is not always the case. This casual equivalence is taught in schools but it is an historical misinterpretation. Entropy calculations are never concerned with order or disorder, they always follow the energy.

Entropy is measured in joules per Kelvin not degree of randomness. It relates to the degree of complexity of interactions in a system, sure. If there was a closed system and all of the energy in that system reached equilibrium and was pure entropy the system would have just reached its most complex form (the most 1s and 0s to identify that system). This does not make it random. Since matter cannot be created or destroyed the universe is a finite closed system that can have extremely complex entropy but is not random. The theory still holds true that if all information in the system could be know it would be predictable infinitely forwards and backwards.  To me, believing in randomness is like believing in God and creation.  Sure I can't disprove it and you can use it to explain observations you don't yet understand (the location of an electron), but all observable matter and chemical interactions are not random and obey laws and there's no reason to believe that they don't obey laws at a quantum level as well, they are just poorly understood.

Quantum randomness doesn't give you free will, anymore than flipping a coin to decide what to eat does. It's also, perhaps more, plausible that there are two different universes where each outcome occurs, and it isn't random at all... just our perception of it in one universe seems random.

It's a nice comforting thought, but it draws false parallels because entropy used in the 2 scenarios are not defined the same way.

When talking about information, entropy is the lack of patterns. The entropy of a video file in this sense will not increase nor decrease no matter how you "compress" (not now compression is actually done but compression without losing any information) it.

when talking about entropy of a system, it's not the lack of patterns. We can very much have a system that we know the present state of, and will be able to know the future state of, despite them having difference entropy. Imagine a physics simulation of 2 gasses each on one half of a container (i specify physics simulation because in this case we know exactly what is happening). At some time t we will have higher entropy due to the gasses mixing, but knowing that future state gives us nothing we didn't already know from the initial state. Information did not increase with entropy.

So despite it being a nice video, that's a logical fallacy and a half if I ever saw one.

If you condense information it doesn't become random. If you would condense the same data in the same way you would end up with the same result, and you could also decompress the data.

And yes, quantum physics is probabilistic but that does not mean random. It's like counting cows as you drive down a countryside road -- you will end up with a probability but that does not mean that the cows were created in the same instance as you saw them. If the road is time and the cows are quantum events, it makes perfectly deterministic sense that the events were not created in the instance you happen to experience them.

It comes down to the definition of randomness, is it "unpredictable" or "not abiding to any rule". Driving down the countryside road you cannot reach 100% certainty when the next cow is going to appear before all cows are counted and the journey has ended. Yet, they still follow the rules of the universe and anyone with complete information can easily determine where they are. Whether or not quantum events or cows are truely random boils down to one thing; if the initial 'seed' of the universe itself, in the instant it and all of its events through time were all created, was truely random or governed by some higher extrauniversal set of laws.

Great video! I love the different concepts you've brought together to address this fascinating concept. One criticism I have, though, has to do with the end bit about free will. I totally agree with you that quantum mechanics does provide that spark of "randomness" which could make human behavior fundamentally unpredictable. However, I don't think that provides sufficient evidence for free will. Just because you don't know what someone will do, doesn't mean they have a CHOICE. Imagine rolling a die or flipping a coin when deciding what to order on a menu from a restaurant. Perhaps the result is unpredictable, but can you really say that you used free will to make the choice? No. You are a slave to the probabilistic rules of quantum mechanics (just as in a deterministic universe you would be a slave to the rules of classical mechanics). Sure--a quantum world SEEMS a bit like it has room for free will, but even a fundamentally unpredictable world doesn't really provide evidence for human agency.

Maybe I'm not fully understanding it, but I think there's a false equivalence drawn between compression and randomness which makes the transitive correlation to entropy invalid. Compression is the reduction to a singularity but you're not increasing the randomness because that information needs to go elsewhere. You're just moving it. The replacement of strings condenses it into a pattern that's signified by a character or set of characters. And the resultant file undergoes another pass to recognize more patterns from the results of the previous pass. The patterns don't disappear. They are held in a key or somewhere else to signify the changes to the file. That information is still there although the size of the video or file would be smaller. You are right though that the value of the data in the keys would be greater and proportional to the data it represents. But that doesn't mean that the incompressible result is totally random. In fact it becomes a singular unit. Which can be represented also in the key with an instance of 1. It's complete order but the order is arranged elsewhere.

If the compressed file is not fully random but really a singular instantiation of a pattern that requires a key to uncompress it, then how can it be congruent to entropy? It can't because entropy is randomness but file compression only appears to be if we ignore the stored keys. I think this is due to the limits of our empiricism and understanding in general. Let's not jump to conclusions, because the absence of an explanation doesn't mean the confirmation of the absence. We just don't know it yet. So I'll take the last 3 minutes of this video with a grain of salt.

There's no such thing as random. Think about it...

Say I have binary input files of length n which are zero-padded, so that 'smaller' files have more zeros at the front. Then I have a compression algorithm that tries to compress the information so that there are more leading zeros. There are 2^n possible input files, and there must be at least 2^n corresponding output files, otherwise information can be lost by the algorithm. So if some files are compressed, there must be others that are expanded by the algorithm.

I think this hypothesis, that entropy is information, and that it can only increase due to quantum mechanics, is wrong. Let's take John Conway's game of life. All of the information on the board can be stored as either a one - a filled space, or a zero - an unfilled space. If you have a row of ten filled spaces, that would be easy to store. You would only need the number of cells before the row, and have them all be zero, then the cells in the row, and have them all be one, and then go to the end of the frame and all of those unfilled spaces are zero. So let's say its x cells before and after the row, it would be: repeat 0 x times, repeat 1 ten times, repeat zero x times. Now, if you let the predictable laws of the game run, it will turn into 3 rows of eight in the next step instead of 1 row of ten. So now it looks like repeat 0 x times, repeat 1 eight times, repeat 0 y times, repeat 1 eight times, repeat 0 y times, repeat 1eight times, repeat 0 x times. So you've increased the amount of information you need to describe the state of the system with absolutely zero randomness.

I applaud your commitment to trying to explain these difficult concepts in more understandable terms, but content wise what you say is - especially in this video - simply wrong. Take your description of quantum mechanics or any other physical concept: The main point about these is, that they are CONCEPTS, they are the best models we can currently INVENT to match what we perceive. The 2nd Law of Thermodynamics isn’t a law of the universe, it’s a law in the models. And the problem with mixing models and reality comes, when you try to explain abstract, nearly metaphysical phenomena based on these concepts, it just doesn’t make sense, on a categorical level. Now lots of people don’t get, or I should say weren’t taught about, the idea of models vs reality, but if you’re going to make an educational popular science channel, please don’t propagate such misconceptions.

Amazing video which tries to tackle the old philosophical debate of determinism vs free will using quantum mechanics. Even so, there are a few points I'd like to make: 1. Just because the universe appears inherently random to us on the most fundamental level, does not mean that it is. We obviously don't fully understand how everything works, yet, and perhaps never will. For instance, we know quantum particles are probability waves, we know about the uncertainty principle, but why are they the way they are? You can always ask the question "why?", ad infinitum, which is why we may never have a full understanding. I.e. "why did the big bang occur?, and why did that occur? etc." 2. Just because the random nature of quantum mechanics manifests as our brains, our CNS, our eyes, and other senses, which manifests as our consciousness, still does not necessarily mean that our consciousness has any influence or control over the universe... But perhaps it can? It's possible we will never know.

I disagree with Derek's idea that the Laplacian view, the view that one can know the future if the velocities and the positions of every particle at a given time are known, is invalidated by the second law of thermodynamics, the law of entropy. If we restrict ourselves to strictly classical physics, both laws can be valid and are not mutually exclusive. The second law has been around much longer than quantum mechanics, and the randomness that a classical chaotic system exhibits arises from a lack of information about every single particle in the system, not from the quantum mechanical randomness of the particle. For example, a dice roll is random because you don't know all of the forces acting on the die. If you knew all of the forces and velocities associated with the dice roll, it would be completely deterministic. Since classical randomness is due to the lack of information of a system and not due to some intrinsic property of matter which is the case for quantum mechanics, the Laplacian view that the world is deterministic still holds. A classically deterministic world and a world in which the second law holds can simultaneously exist without paradox, which is the opposite of what Derek was saying near the end of the video.

Keep in mind that I was just talking about classical physics. Of course, randomness in quantum mechanics is not the same. The randomness of a particle in quantum mechanics is an intrinsic property of the particle itself and does not arise from lack of information the same way that it does in classical mechanics. Quantum mechanics actually invalidates the Laplacian view because of the uncertainty principle, and thus opens up the possibility of non deterministic concepts like free will in terms of physical law, as what Derek was mentioning in the video, but this is was not my point. My point is that classically, the Laplacian view and the second law are not mutually exclusive.

Perhaps quantum mechanics introduces randomness, but if one would know about all of the randon quantum events the instant they happen, one would then have all the information in the universe.
This means it isn't possible to determine the future based on one instant (knowing the positions and movement of each particle) but one would have to constantly observe all particles and quantum events.

However, this still wouldn't be enough to predict the future. Because at any point in time after the last observation has been made, there will be an unpredictable quantum event.

So the only way to know the future of the universe is to know all quantum events in the future too.

In other words: the only way to know the future is to know the future.

It is still possible that these quantum events are not random, but simply unpredictable by humans/in our three dimensions. This would mean that determinism is true, while at the same time the future is not predictable.

Wait, but what if the only reason we could not predict the position of electrons was because we were not capable of it with our current technology, or with our current way of thinking? What if in the future, we found a way to observe (In the scientific sense, not just visually) the movement of electrons, then we would theoretically be able to predict everything, given the information?  But if we could observe/quantify every lurking variable in the future, then nothing would be truly random, other than the source of it all. Well, it would still seem random to all of us, because we are incapable of understanding/integrating all the information without condensing it in our minds. We would have an abstract form of predictions. Either way, the electrons still have limits themselves though. So it shouldn't take us too much longer to start to grasp the alleged true randomness of electrons. The only way for the electrons movement to be truly random, is if our current knowledge of the movement is incomplete. All we have to do is find out what we are missing, even if it is something that may seem supernatural or unlikely at our current understanding of things.

For ex.:
Consider this string : 100100100100100100100
If we have a rule which is being applied on this string, that can increase information contained in this string with time.

100101100101100110100100111
Which contain more information.

I watched this video a while ago and have been thinking today about one of the arguments presented. I do not know if this has already been exposed here in the comments, but I think that compressing information to its limit does not mean making it "pure information." This is because, in fact, it lacks a part of the system there: the interpreter. The greater the compression of an information, the more complex its interpreter will be. So what you do when compressing a message is nothing more than transferring some of the information to the interpreter. This implies that pure information is even more ordered (much less entropy) than any message we can imagine, for it would possess all the information of its interpretation along with it (which I think is impossible).

So if we could somehow predict exactly what was going to happen in the universe (like he said in the video), because we knew its information . The prediction would not be accurate, due to random quantum effects that are independent of our prediction. These effects change the universe on a small scale, but render our predictions useless.

But what if you analysed when these random quantum effects occurred over a long period of time? you could look at how many occur per billion years or so and compared them, worked out an average etc. We could have as much information as we want on these "random effects", but we could never predict exactly when they will occur.

It seems like information cannot carry(contain) information bigger than itself, it can only get smaller. Hence entropy.

The mysterious unknown information of these "random effects" defines how everything turned out the way it did and what makes us unique at this point in time compared to the last.

On the topic of entropy, the law states that on a macro-state things tend to (collectively) become more and more disordered. However, that does not mean that on a micro-state that systems cannot go from disorder to order (as the evolution of man shows). All that it means is that if one system has a negative amount of entropy, the universe will make up for it somewhere else (weather patterns, for example) with a positive amount of entropy (more disorder, yay).

I reject the premise that QM or entropy means sub atomic particles are random. Random only means we don't have all the necessary information to make a definite prediction. Not that the information doesn't exist. Uncertainty principle no more proves true randomness than someone who is unaware of a slot machines algorithm and therefore can't predict the next winning spin. To claim that true randomness exists is to say that there are some instances in which physical laws don't apply. Hard determinism for the win.

There is a really important distinction that you gloss over (possibly even falsely conflate) between informational entropy and entropy in thermodynamics. Please see here for the father of information theory's opinion on this distinction: https://monoskop.org/images/2/2f/Shannon_Claude_E_1956_The_Bandwagon.pdf
Also, with the whole "Finding an electron" example this is actually just incorrect. The observation of the position of a particle at one moment in time yes technically increases the information you have at that moment about its position, but not only does this tell you nothing about the position of the particle in the future, but to continue your analogy you lose as much information as you gain because when you observe one aspect of a quantum state (like position) the other aspects (like momentum) are inherently *unknowable*. This is the essence of the uncertainty principle...

I may be badly misunderstanding, but I seem to remember that the increasing entropy of a classical state results from the decreasing entropy of entanglement. As particles interact, they can become entangled with each other, producing an entangled state that can only be completely described as a whole; the two particles have no independent description and can only be described together. Entangled particles have less entropy than pure particles because some of the information is shared, meaning you need fewer bits of information to describe the entire state of both particles than you would to describe each particle independently if they were not entangled.

So as particles interact thermodynamically, the system containing them tends to lose entanglement entropy and gain thermodynamic entropy. Since information is conserved, these two rates must be equal, and thus the "total" entropy in the universe in this sense is actually constant. While the number of microstates satisfying the macrostate of a system's present configuration increases, the number of bits of information required to describe the quantum properties of the particles involved decreases. At heat death, particles would all be maximally entangled, and thus at minimum entanglement entropy; as such, the thermodynamic entropy of the universe could increase no further and would be at a maximum.

However, I don't think it's correct to attribute the existence of the Second Law to Quantum Mechanics. The Second Law would still be true in a universe without Quantum Mechanics.

Thermodynamic entropy is related to how many micro-situations (locations and momenta of particles) are compatible with a given set of macroscopic variables (temperature, pressure, volume...). A macrostate with high entropy means that there's more of those microstates compatible with it.

The reason that entropy increases with time is that, the more microstates a macrostate has associated, the more probable it is that the system is found in it. (In reality, the real question is why was the universe in such a low entropy state to begin with).

Quantum mechanics is not needed for this to be true, so I don't see how QM could be the source for that entropy.

The randomness of the universe actually has nothing to do with determinism... and a world with free wil can exist in a fully deterministic universe ... How you might ask? Well if all the option were simply predetermined, aka 'deterministic on a higher order', you could still choose between the options. What happens after that choice isn't then 'random', no it has consequences that are predetermined (to put it in an analogy: a river delta is deterministic, the route a twig takes through the delta how ever is not; given it has some free will that is) ... the other predetermined things just do not happen, or do they?

And the Entropy of the universe might not be increasing by the outcome of quantum events 'per see', it's more likely it is increasing 'in the past' once the event happens. Say you are at point A and want to get to point B, there are 3 routes to get to point B (entropy is 3 so to speak) ... You pick one ... but once you arrive at point B it doesn't really matter which route you took, right? So, for al intend and purpose, you took them all ... but here is a funny thing, you arrived at B, and there are 4 more routes to C ... does the universe really know you came from A once you arrived at B ?! ... no! ... so not only did you take the 3 routes from A to B, you also took the 4 routes from C to B ...

So it looks as though reality is a bit like the Dual Split experiment, only both forward as well as backwards. At any point you have the chance/choice space ahead of you, but behind you in time are also all the chances and choices that lead you to this time/space.

Say for some reason you have to amputate your leg, once it happened, even though 'you know when or how', for the universe you may as well have lost it at birth, or anytime in between, or yesterday. And thus maybe in essence you do? ... and thus, at every event the entropy increases ... and it has to, i just realized, for there to be free will and seeming randomness... due to the law of causality ... maybe events aren't random at all, they are simply a causal event of a past that might have happened, given the current state of the universe. Because it doesn't know which past actually happened... and thus all of them might as well have happened, in which case a random thing can exist without breaking any causal relation...

Ohw, and yes, due to this i am also fairly convinced there aren't 'multiple universes', the universe can exist quite perfectly as a standalone, because all the 'multiples' are caught within the chance-space of the future and the past.

Free will is logically impossible. You can never have free will, not in any possible world. In short, things are either determined or indetermined, there is no middle ground. When I say free will, I simply mean that one has the ability to truly choose between option A or option B; to pick up the cup of water or to not pick up the cup of water.

For something to be determined is to say that events are governed by their antecedents. Prior causes will necessarily entail a particular outcome. The whole world and all of the events that have taken place are merely a series of chain reactions like that of watching dominos fall. This means that when the big bang occurred, if we could measure all of the physical variables that were present, we could predict the outcome of some event billions of years into the future.

For something to be indetermined is to suggest that events are not reliably governed by their antecedents/prior causes. Instead, events are inherently and fundamentally random. This means that there would be no way of predicting some event billions of years in the future by simply knowing all of the physical variables during the big bang. It is like pushing a domino and then some fall and some stand with no particular order or sense to it.

What you will notice is that in either these scenarios, there is no gap for free will to exist. If things are determined, you were always going to pick up that glass of water and by doing so, you are simply observing that domino fall into place. If things are indeterminded, you picking up the glass of water is out of your control due to the fact that it was based upon fundamentally random events. There is an intuition and misconception that indeterminism = free will, all it means is that your decisions are at bottom random and that you cannot predict them. This once again does not leave any room for truly choosing between option A and option B.

Free will is simply an illusion and it is fun to snap in and out of that illusion when you understand and accept these arguments.

There is an interesting connection of predeterminedness (or maybe even an equivalence?) with pure functional programming. Everything inside an isolated pure environment (some programming languages use monads for isolation) has perfectly determined past and future form entry to exit of the "purity bubble". All the "random" information is encoded on the "surface" of the bubble. Seemingly imperative unpredictable side effects (that is: random stuff around the bubble) can often be packaged up to be pure again if fully understood and isolated well enough at a higher level.

Coined on physics that would mean that "space-time purity bubbles" of predeterminedness can be made increasingly bigger dependent on the level of your knowledge (which depends on how long you manage to live in face of "random" attacks that the universe has in store). The question here though is: Is quantum randomness a fundamental limit for that onion like repackaging idea so that beyond this point things become fundamentally unpredictable?

Maybe it's just a very big jump to the next packaging level. (only weak global consistency requirements)

Maximum entropy is EXTREMELY ordered and EXTREMELY predictable and contains the least amount of information possible about a system. If the universe died of heat death, or a state of maximum entropy, the entire universe would be completely filled with only one thing. Entropy is simply the increase of one type of order (symmetry order) that is inversely related to another type of order (Grouping order.) "We know this because everything in the universe is made of 12 fundamental particles, and they interact in 4 predictable ways". I really feel like scientists should be careful about using the word "because" - especially in this instance, since we are talking about a borderline philosophical question. I mean, ultimately, the only reason why we can postulate that what happens tomorrows is predictable is simply that we have observed yersterday, and the day before that, and the day before,... that all things that happen have some regularity to them, and we have ultimately boiled our observations down to some laws that explain what we observe (and sometimes things we have not observed yet). But there is nothing preventing the laws of nature to change tomorrow morning at 06 am, other than that this would violate all our previous observations. Saying stuff like the above quote is in my opinion an overly educated explanation - what you are basically saying is that in all the documented history of mankind we have observed a lot of phenomena to be predictable and following certain rules, matter being made up of this and that and so forth, and we therefore postulate that tomorrow all the same rules apply since they have always done that as far as we know. Don't fool yourself into thinking that the fundamental quantum theories we know are anything more than the systemization of our finest observations of Nature. The 4 fundamental forces in physics only "bind" future events insofar that we believe that these laws will also govern our world tomorrow. So, ultimately, I think it is wrong to say that events happen because of these laws. Conversely, we have discovered the laws because events happen as they have always been observed to do. To believe in Science is to believe that the regularities we observe will persist and have always existed. Physics is fundamentally an experimental science, you know. Rant over. No offense intended.

The entire premise of this video is faulty. Entropy does not match up to order/chaos. Initial conditions of a perfect gas in a set volume would require a differing description of the gas at each moment and coordinate. After a time, the gas will become homogeneous in temperature, density, pressure, etc. In other words, entropy is the moving toward a MORE ordered system, but one from which usable work-energy becomes less available. Moving from more potentials to less potentials. The reason you cant predict the future with 100% accuracy is because seeing the future is affecting the future. Traditionally when you try to predict the future you take everything into account except that you are predicting the future and the results will "only" be a 100% accurate representation of the future where you didnt predict it. This is how you try to predict the future with 100% accuracy: Add everything into the equation + the results then add everything + the results + the results of that then add everything + the results of the results of everything + the results then add etc etc into infinity.

The future is not random but it is also not predictable with 100% accuracy because predicticng it changes it.

Here a paradox/example how it would turn out in real life: You know your friend will go to work all days this week. You tell him you can predict his future and if you are wrong you will give him 1 million dollars. His "future" is that he is going to go to work everyday this week. As long as you dont tell him your predicition he will go to work everyday this week most likely but if you reveal the prediction to him it will change the outcome and he will stay at home in order to win the bet.

Having revealed your prediction to him changes the future and you will have to add the new prediction into acount in order to not loose the bet.

this is a pretty weak argument and premise.

if you were strict about your definition of 'understanding the universe at any one time' then there is no more or less entropy at any point in the future or the past, since you would describe every element, every particle, every atom, nucleus and electron etc in absolute terms (and not in relation to what they are connected to, ie: their absolute position, rotation, and so on).

in this way, there is absolutely no more information going on in the future.

The confusion here in this video is it assumes one would use 'logical compression' by saying 'this is a cube of so and so dimensions with so many blah blah atoms' rather than individually described - then in the future it gets exploded and must be described individually, suddenly requiring a longer explanation (more 'information') to describe it - however that is only because in this scenario you failed to describe it 'in absolute terms' to begin with.

so yeah, they are just playing a fun word game. nothing more.

I liked the notion that the laws of physics are a way of 'compressing' the universe. But a lack of predictability in our mental events still doesn't allow for free will. Quantum mechanical laws are just as outside our control as deterministic laws. In other words, any indeterminacy in how our mental events unfold is due to the randomness involved in the way the universe operates, and not due to some sort of uncaused 'self'.

To say we're 'free to think otherwise' in the next moment, only if the dice happen to roll the right way, wouldn't actually be thinking otherwise on our own steam, so to speak. But the bottom line for me is that free will is a contradiction in terms. Your next thought can't be both free (uninfluenced by anything) and also willed (influenced by some aspect of your personality).

The only reason entropy increases is because there are more positions or situations that are not orderly. We have to understand that things change in the universe. So if something contains order, and it changes, either it will change to something else that is orderly or something else that is not. According to probability, disorder. By a large degree.

If you throw a cup to the floor, you are changing the cup. The structure of the cup was orderly until you changed it. Now what is the probability that it changed into something else that is orderly? Perhaps the shattered pieces landed in a format that spelled your name? The probability is extremely low.

Now really we should ask, what is order? Order is something that follows a certain pattern or rule that makes things easier to comprehend.

Now there are things that do tend towards order. Things being in groups are one of the primary properties of order. Why? Because it follows the idea of being near to a certain position, hence easier to comprehend. Take gravity for example; in many circumstances, gravity does tend towards order. It pulls everything together, making groups of matter, which is more understandable and more orderly. There are many other examples of things in nature that tend towards order.

There are things in nature that happen to tend towards order but also intelligence can lead towards order. Think about this. Suppose you are in a maze. If nature behaves in a "random" sort of manner, it would not be able to get through the maze without coming to a dead end. But since intelligence can understand the idea of order, it's like a red line drawn on the right path to the end of the maze. We can understand the actions or changes we have to take to lead towards order. Unlike nature that changes things "randomly", which by probability, leads towards disorder.

Probably not... I'd like to bring your attention to "The Standard Argument Against Free-Will"
1. The concept of indeterminism contradicts free will. (I.E. random does not equal choice)
2. The concept of determinism also contradicts that of free will.
3. Some occurrences are governed by determinism, and all the rest by indeterminism.

all of which lead to the conclusion:

4. Free will does not govern any occurrences (does not exist).

Or if you prefer quotes from the well known...

"Recent developments in physical science [viz., quantum indeterminacy] have come into play here, and the freedom of the human will has been put forward as offering logical grounds for the acceptance of only a statistical causality operative in the physical universe. As I have already stated on other occasions, I do not at all agree with this attitude. If we should accept it, then the logical result would be to reduce the human will to an organ which would be subject to the sway of mere blind chance."

- Max Planck

I have some interrogations about what you're explaining here.

You say that information that is not random can be compressed, but in my opinion that raises 2 questions :

- How de you define "compress" ? I think you can't define it without giving a method for the compression. If you define "compresse the string '00010'' as the fact that you can write it more simply, you can imagine a way of compression that is a dictionnary, for example : { '00010 > 0, '00000'>1, etc} that can allows you to "compress" '00010', following your definition. If one argue that the "compression" should not use an arbitrary dictionnary, one should remember that the way you compressed things ( "repeat(0)" for instance), also use a dictionnary (the english one).

- That leads me to my second interrogation: what do you define as random ? If you wish to pick a random binary number between, let's say, 0000000000 and 1111111111, you have à chance to pick the number 0000000000, wich, following your definition, can be compressed as "repeat(0)*10". So, is 0000000000 not random ? How many of the random numbers between 0000000000 and 1111111111 are not really randoms ? For me, that is a proof that you can't talk about "compressing" something without expliciting the space where the things you want to compress are, the compression function and the space of the resulting compressions (let's call it F). With this formalism, i agree that you can't compress anything in the F space, if your compression function was powerfull enough, without loosing information.

Given this formalism, which i believe is necessary, I think that the physical extrapolations you make are abusives.

Not that I say that the result is wrong, but the way you explained it doesn't seem logically convincing to me. Anyway, I really enjoy all your videos, and you really put effort into making people question what they are told.

+Veritasium Around 5:50 about the argument "against a Laplace-deterministic universe". The fact that entropy increases has nothing to do with the fact the universe is deterministic or not: by example, if you assume our universe is restricted (physically and by its laws) to a single volume in which there is a perfect gas (small balls moving independently and bouncing at the volume limits) you have a perfectly deterministic and reversible universe but nevertheless you'll observe macroscopic phenomenon that still happen in only one direction: the diffusion of such a gas in the volume. The reasons are statistical.
The entropy of the diluted state is thus strictly higher than the entropy of the same gas concentrated somewhere in our finite volume. And so as it's possible to built the laws of such deterministic universe in which we can still talk about entropy and second principle of thermodynamics, it rules out any argument saying this mechanism proves we live in a undeterministic universe.

Increase in entropy of the universe does not imply random universe.

I’ll try to keep this as short as I can. So .. random vs deterministic
Say we have initial state 0101 and state transition rules (0 turns to 1, 1 turns to 0) then the states will be:
0101
1010
0101
..
Etc.
This is what I call deterministic (or non-random). We know every single state given the initial state and state transition rules. Now if after a few states I do this:

0101
1010
0111 <- manually modified the state
1000
0111

This is random because given the initial state and the state transition rules I can’t predict all the other states. The same definition applies to the universe, a state being the combination of all the unit “particles” in the physical universe (and not just the ones that we think we know of), and transition rules being the unit “forces” that act on them.
Now, what I call entropy is the size of the minimum amount of information that is necessary to describe a state. For ex.

State 01011010 is two (01) followed by two (10). So let’s say we have this state, and transition rules are (01 -> 10) and (10 -> 01). So the sequence is:
State ------- Entropy
01011010 -> two (01) followed by two (10)
10100101 -> two (10) followed by two (01)
01011010 -> two (01) followed by two (10)
…
Etc
As we can see the entropy stays constant all the time, and we have a deterministic system. But now if we had the exact same initial state but transition rules (01) moves 2 digits to the right and (10) stays the same we’ll have the sequence.

State ------- Entropy
01011010 -> two (01) followed by two (10)
10010110 -> one (10) followed by two (01) followed by one (10)

As you can see, entropy increased here but we still have a non-random (deterministic) system. The universe could be the same way. If unit forces that act on the unit particles change the “location” of a particle within the universe (given some small “distance” in the change) we will still see a non-random universe with gradually increasing entropy.
So… increasing entropy does not entail random universe...

Where does information come from? The only source is: a mind. Let me explain.

These guys are talking about Shannon information (developed by Claude Shannon). However, it's not necessarily MEANINGFUL information.

There's a difference between Shannon information (order) and meaningful information. Example: "we hold these truths to be self evident"...."ntnyhiznslhtgeqkahgdsjnfplknejmsed." These two sentences are equally long and equally improbable if we imagine them to be drawn at random. They contain the same amount of Shannon information.

My question is this: Where does meaningful information come from? We see it in physics, we especially see it in biology (DNA), and we see it in the world around us. The only source of information that I know of is a mind. An intelligence.

I hate to be that guy, but I'm 3 minutes into the video and already disturbed by 2 statements. Need to get it out of my system, here we go:
1st (I'm paraphrasing): "if you knew the movement and interaction of all particles etc. everything would be perfectly predictable/ nothing would be random." This deterministic view has long been disproven, with e.g. the half life phenomenon, which let's you predict how much mass will decay, but never which one of the identical atoms will decay next, no matter how perfect your information. Or with the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, which proves that you can never know location and motion of a particle at the same time. There is no determinism, no matter how perfect your information. (Does this mean we have free will? No.)
2nd: "Disorder is what we also call entropy." This is a very vague, popular statement. If disorder were entropy and entropy must always increase, then all mass in the universe at one point would be higher order than all the mass distributed equally. And thus gravitation would defy entropy. Therefore, entropy can not be equivalent to disorder. Rather, it describes the lowest energy state of things.

All of the above is what a first semester physics student could tell you btw, nothing fancy.

I have an idea for how both "God not playing dice", and quantum mechanics can be true at the same time. Well, it's probably poorly worded, I'm a little sleepy at the moment, but..

You could call it shy dependency. Picture 2 dimensions, and a communication between them. You live in the first dimension, however you are able to observe the second. Observing the second takes a bit of time to receive the information, by which point the second dimension realises you are observing it and consequently changes its dependency upon your dimension. Lets use some basic equations to demonstrate what I mean: x = y+4, and y = x*2. Even though these two equations depend on each other, there is a clear value (x = -4). The moment x tries to find out what y equals, y reveals its value, but then changes it in some way based on what x is, for example it becomes y = x*5 (x's value to y is now -1). Now x finds out that y = x*2, but this information is already outdated. You could say x could try to predict the pattern that y uses to establish it's new formula, but y would realise that the next time y observes x and will then change the way it works according to the way it thinks x works. If x actually tried to calculate y, y would do the same and it would end up in an infinite calculation and never actually reach a conclusion (an I know that you know conundrum), it therefore cannot be calculated, and so each has to take the other's word for it. So, at any time, neither x nor y can ever know their true dependency, and so they are always wrong in respect to each other.

Long story short, this would work if whenever you observe any one part of the universe, your observation is always wrong about that part.

I have something like a theory (or... a thought experiment), called "The Principle of the inside-out socks" :-). The idea is, that the Time may not always be necessarily running "forwards". It can go backwards "for a while", in the same sense that the current CPU's are processing data - they take consecutive instructions, "parallelize" them (running them concurrently, if possible) and at the end of the pipeline they sequence them again - according to their dependencies, conserving the "sense" of the algorithm.

It's been more that 20 years since processors started to do that (Cyrix M1) and I think it's time to consider this model as a possible explanation of some quantum effects - specifically those, that "require" going back in time [for a particle] to do something that's happening [to our perceptions] Now. The idea is - you don't need to reverse the cause->effect direction to do something "in the past". It's enough for that Past to be still "present" at the moment! (One such good reason, for ex., why a certain "past" may still be... not passed yet, is the Catastrophe theory.)

Now, combine this with the Anthropic principle! ;-)

My idea is that, if such mathematical Catastrophes exist (i.e. inability - not only for a computer - but for a Reality "to calculate" the next step), then there should be some way to define the further steps of such a system. And it doesn't need to be done NOW - such system can stay in undefined state - possibly growing bigger (with its interactions with other systems), until an Observer decides to measure/observe/experience it! Then - "my theory" comes in effect, in such case, a possible Observer in the future (who's observing the possible consequences of this undefined state/s) could actually... DEFINE them! Thus, effectively, changing the Past! :-)

It's just an assumption, It's just an idea, but anyway - decided to share it...

(I also have developed the philosophical background of this theory (stating for ex. that "if something is possible, it should be doable"), and ALSO the mathematical methods to demonstrate it and [possibly] prove it. If someone's interested, pls msg me!)

Randomness is limited at the early Universe right after the Big bang, while high in the late Universe, until the Heat Death (thermodynamical uniformity of energy) enters the scene. This is well confirmed by the general increase of entropy in the Universe (you need more energy to decrease entropy for a locality than to increase it) ,seen together with natural evolution going into more and more complexity. It is also shown in how we know the matter from atom to molecule has become more complex the colder the area of space was. 

Imagine that you blow up a grenade, and instead of pieces laying to rest on the ground, they continue in a timespace where local areas have a potential of variation governed by how strong the explosion's energy exists in the pieces and their internal relations. Finally after an immense time passed, the energy will be dissolved into the maximum saturation. At this point there is no randomness and no determinedness.

So all is causal variation. The degree of chaos increases within a limited potential (our Universe). For the same reason we get variation in results reaching a normal division if tossing a coin many times. It could only have been "heads only" or the opposite into eternity, if there was true randomness or oneline-determined universe. But as the universe is causal variative, the results will reach variation early if there are few potential locally and high equality of the potentials (like in coin toss).

The unpredictability of the Quantum world is a weakness of observation and logic relevant enough for the extremely small realms of events. The smaller something is, the more frenetic relative to its size and its environment. So an object with a large percentage of "empty space" contra "matter/particles" will at our perspective of view seem and feel and be very physical.

At the end of Voyager series 3, the writers wanted to introduce a new character, but because the budget only allowed for a certain number of main actors, they had to let one of them go. Originally this was going to be Harry Kim, played by Garrett Wang, who had been very vocal in his hate for the show. (This is why there's a weird cliffhanger with him about to die that gets almost immediately overturned in series 4).
People Magazine then ran a list of the Hottest 50 Men which included Wang. Seeing he was popular, they decided to get rid of the character Kes, played by Jennifer Lien, whose character they thought they'd messed up a bit and run out of ideas.
Since Kes leaving left them with only two major female characters, they decided to make their new character female as well, leading to them making Seven of Nine, played by Jeri Ryan.
For filming, she had to move to California, which put strain on her already damaged relationship with Jack Ryan and led to their divorce. In 2004, the messy details of their divorce came out, forcing Jack Ryan to stand down from running for the position of Senator of Illinois, allowing a relatively new Barack Obama to win. Four years later, Obama became President of the US.

I've heard this idea that the randomness of QM gives rise to "free will". Before putting forth such an hypothesis, we should ask whether free will exists at all. An alternate theory is that consciousness is "epiphenomenal". That is, our thoughts are not the cause of our actions (obviously, they are correlated, so the theory would suggest that thoughts and actions have a common cause). Studies based on brain scans indicate that thoughts occur AFTER the initial neural impulse that causes actions. I don't understand how such a study can possibly work, but that's what I read in books that my college professors told me to read. Anyway, the upshot of epiphenomenalism is that "free will" is an illusion. One counter-argument is that if consciousness is epiphenomenal, then it would be a tremendous waste of energy, and therefore, would be very unlikely to survive natural selection. Of course, such arguments are generally dubious, because Evolution does NOT say that NS optimizes away all bad things; it only makes incremental improvements, one mutation at a time. Such features are known as vestigial. E.g. the human appendix appears to have negative survival benefit (an infection can kill you; whereas, people who have had their appendix removed do not seem to suffer lower mortality) yet we still have them. Examples of vestigial features that are more curious: whales sometimes have little stumps where their legs would be (such stumps increase energy required to swim), even though most members of the species do not have such stumps. Some humans are born with little tails, which can be surgically removed.

IMO there is another reason independent of quantum mechanics why the current "configuration" of the universe (and hence its future) is fundamentally unknowable. To know every single property of every single particle in the universe means to also know every single property of every single particle of you, since you are part of that universe. Essentially it would imply knowing ahead of time every single decision you are ever going to make. But how can that be when you could basically just say Screw that! and then make the opposite decision just out of spite, thereby throwing off that supposedly predetermined plan for the universe?

Do you see where I'm going with this? Because I can't quite seem to put it into clear and concise enough words, but it would basically create a kind of chicken/egg problem, maybe even an outright logical paradox with regard to knowing all of your own future decisions ahead of time.

Also, another way to look at order and disorder is to think they as constituents of a wave... that is, when you zoom something in or out, it appears that order and disorder alternates at different levels. At one level everything seems like the same, no matter at what direction you look. If you go further, some entities will show up, and they will have distinct parts. Zoom more, and entities cannot be seen, and things look boring again, continue zooming (in/out) and another entity will appear.

I liked the point of view relating entropy and compression. Here's another way to look at it: compression is about exchanging large meaningful sequences with small meaningless ones. By "meaningful" I mean, sequences that repeat more often than not, and "meaningless" the opposite, sequences that are quite not observed at all. For that, an exchange table must be build... so compression requires rules, known before compressing or decompressing.

Where is this extra information coming from? Nowhere. There is no extra information, at least from the perspective of Laplace's "intelligence".

Entropy only exists from a human perspective. Entropy represents the erosion of the structured patterns we use to perceive the universe (such as galaxies, planets, people and atoms). That erosion occurs as our structures interact with each other and change in unpredictable (to us) ways, but to the "intelligence," the exact same number of units of energy exist after each interaction. They simply are changing direction, in ways it can easily calculate.

This is true due to the fact that the "intelligence" was always perceiving the universe with the lowest possible compression. To it, our current, structured universe is no different than the one that will theoretically exist at the end of time, where all atoms have evaporated and every photon is travelling alone.

th:
That --> This
   ^ Those ^
Thus, many words beginning with "th" do not contain an "e" in the third place.
That I can type this comment without following "th" immediately with an "e" should show how an assumption that "th" is followed by "e" is naive.
Thinking on it, an assumption that "th" is followed by "o" is just as likely to be true, after all, we have though, thought, thorough, thorn...or maybe by "i"; thin, thing, thick, thief.  That "a" or "u" follow "th" seems a good assumption, as "that" and "than" are common words, though thane, thaw, thus, and thug are not; I could argue that "r" is just as common, as three, throw, threw, and through come to mind.
My point: though "the" is like the most common use of the pairing of "th", it is only one word, and assuming "th" is followed by "e" to make "the" (or any word beginning with "the") is ignorant....especially since "the" is passed over as quickly as "of", as proven by the the puzzles found on the Internet that say "count the number of "f's" in this sentence, or "find the the error".

The only randomness that is acceptable, up to a degree, is a quantum randomness when you make a "measurement" and cause decoherence, even then, there are deterministic interpretations such as Bohmian Mechanics or the Everett Quantum Interpretation.
