" You're reasoning that quantum randomness allows us to have free-will is flawed. Free-will denotes that the agent has the ultimate control, whereas the theory you claim places the ultimate control on the randomness that occurs at the quantum level (since everything else is predetermined). Since the agent cannot control quantum mechanics, he/she does not control his/her decisions in the way that can be defined as free-will."

That's very much debate-able. It's not as if we have a good grasp of what's going on in the brain in the molecular level. As far as we can tell the sense of self may be a quantum effect to begin with which may be why we have the capacity to affect quantum phenomena by the mere act of observation (i.e. Copenhagen interpretation).

So affecting quantum phenomena on one level implies that "we" can affect them on another. More particularly some of those going on in our brains, which do not merely give the possibility of a free will but the eventuality of it.

As for "being conscious of choices after we make them" there are quantum effects that seem to take in accordance events happening (a tiny bit) forward in time as well as those before (for example "Two-state vector formalism"). So if conciousness is a quantum event it may well be happening a bit forward in time (a few micro-seconds).

Obviously all of those is a stretch but none seem to counteract our present knowledge. It merely shows how little we (truly) know about Quantum Mechanics and indeed conciousness...

There is at least one point where the train of thought here gets sloppy. There is a part where the Veritasium fellow says that not all letters in a message convey the same amount of information, and he gives an example of this by saying that if we have the following message:

U-T-E-R-U-S

the last one or two letters could be 'predicted' from the preceding ones, given the particular order in which they are arranged. This means, in this example, that if we were to have the message "U-T-E-R-U", we could safely assume that the intended message is "UTERUS" and so we could deduce the letter "S" without it actually being in the original message. But this only holds true if you are assuming that the message is in the English language, and along with this assumption comes a vast amount of information (not contained in the original message) regarding the use of English language, the correct spelling of words, the frequency of words in normal usage of the language, and other things. So if you say that the last letters in our example above carry less information than the ones at the beginning you are making a mistake because you are taking for granted a big chunk of information that is not conveyed by the message itself. So my contention is that, without making any prior assumptions, the different letters in a message do carry each the same amount of information.

If we tried to predict the letters in a message without any outside information, then we would have no reason to think that "UTERUS" should be derived from "U-T-E-R-U", because the message might as well be in a different language, or just be a random combination characters.

I think it's wrong from him to say those things about free will at the end. He seems to be making a couple assumptions:

1. Determinism rules out free will in our universe.
2. Non-determinism (whatever you wanna call it) leaves room for free will.

Both these assumptions would be wrong. In the 1st case, because you can be a dualist and that way you could have free will and also determinism. In this case the mind would be made up of a different 'substance' than matter, unbound from the constraints of determinism. In the 2nd case, there's also a problem, but before stating that I want to make a clarification of my own on the topic of determinism.

Determinism by definition does not mean "being able to predict the future state of X". It means only that the state of a closed system determines all future states of that same system, regardless of our ability to calculate the actual outcomes. The double pendulum at the end is not undeterministic by the way; the pendulum does have chaotic motion when inertia is applied to it above a certain threshold, and yes we can't actually predict its motion with complete certainty, but that does not make it undeterministic. In fact, the butterfly effect is still a situation of determinism: the initial state, down to the most tiny fluctuations, fully determines the future states of the system. So again the fact that we cannot predict the future state of a system based on its current one does not make that system undeterministic.

Now about the 2nd assumption, that non-determinism leaves open the possibility of free will (or even encourages it). To say this seems to me like a desperate attempt to cling on to the idea of free will; it's as untenable an argument as your run-of-the-mill creationism/ID argument. If non-determinism were true, it still would not make it more likely that free will is possible. Note that we can still approach a probabilistic answer to the question "where is the electron at time 't'?", so we are not completely in the blind. Also, the degree to which the future state of the electron is "random" does not tell us anything about free will, unless we are trying to make peace with the idea that, somehow, our choices operate at the level of somewhat random (not completely, because we can calculate the odds of certain outcomes) quantum events. What I'm trying to say is; if you want to make the case for free will, it needs to be more specific than this. You should not just point to a place where science doesn't yet have all the answers and say "there, there it is (or could be)". That is a fallacy.

In my opinion free will is an illusion; a consequence of being self-aware to such a degree as humans are. It's the way the brain makes things easier for us, bearable so to speak. And we can never really rid ourselves of the illusion, because the brain is wired in such a way as to inevitably pick up on it. Remember that Café Wall optical illusion? You perceive the lines as slanted, but they really are parallel to each other. You can use a ruler or whatever method you like and see for yourself that the lines are indeed parallel to one another. But being aware of the illusion doesn't change the way our brain works: you still perceive the lines as oblique. The same thing happens, in my view, with free will: if it were ever substantially proven that humans (and all other animals for that matter) have no free will, we would still be feeling as though we have free will, and it won't change much our behaviour or our "decisions". Also, know that if you read this far it is because you didn't have a choice. Cheers :)

If you look up Leonard Susskind's video, you will see the fact that randomness can become order by chance after a long long period of time. The second law of thermodynamics is a probabilistic theory itself, meaning, given enough time, the law can be disobeyed for just a brief moment. When that moment arrives, the universe is at time zero again, everything repeats itself again, predictably. 

It is not that simple, as this video describes, that the sheer entropy increase creates the interesting unpredicted future. A few things can accommodate it to make it truly unpredictable. The universe can be non-digital for any state to be not quantized precisely. By the chaos theory, a non-digital universe is not predictable. Quantum mechanics says everything is digital when you go down to the plank scale, however. Quantum mechanics has a huge gap to reconcile with relatively, on the other hand.

In Susskind's research, another way for the future to not repeat the past is to allow patches of space in our universe to die and disappear. When things can disappear, you can't undisappear them because no amount of energy can do it, and hence future can't repeat past.

So, don't be too optimistic about the interesting unpredictable future. We just don't know enough to make the conclusion.

Interesting take on free will. Well, most of the time I don't put "free will" simply as something opposite to determinism. True that quantum events are probabilistic and quantum systems are chaotic, and there could be "quantum events" going on in our brain that cause random events. However, free will is talked about in the context of macroscopic objects, and for human, wether the will is "free" connects to their "decision making": brain event has to go to the scope of "consciousness" to make a decisions, and so to be called "free". If the event is simply subatomic and chaotic, it won't form any decisions in real life. It's only the collection of these events that form decisions and conscious experience, and whether the system as a whole is predictable remains as a question (I don't deny that "free will" is possible, I just doubt whether we're using this word correctly). I overall think that random quantum events can't form the idea of "free will", and we don't need to every single quantum events to predict a macroscopic human behavior.

If the change in the average distance between any 2 particles is greater than 0, entropy will increase. If the change is negative (meaning the particles get closer to each other), entropy will decrease.

Maybe they did this as a joke, but this video isn't true, and it is rather random. They say entropy, or disorder, is information. This is false as there is no such thing as information, it's an illusion. Binary is information that can be read by computers. Words are information that can be read by humans. Without the human, the word means nothing. It is just a representation of something. 
"Kick" represents a physical action. "Kick" is a word, which is just a series of straight and curved lines. 

So, since information is just a representation of something real, information can't be disordered, it has to have a pattern. Information is useless, and effectively nothing but a few lines drawn together with no one who can understand it.

So white noise, that's not max information. It contains nothing understandable, therefore, useless and not information.

You can't treat information as you would treat entropy.

Entropy is disorder. "grsemhklgnmj kgtyrlj,h" is entropy, it can exist without the need of a conscious being to read it.

"Hello" Is information. It means something. Without humans though, it is not information. So the information "hello" contains does not exist unless someone is there to read it, even though the symbols do exist.

tl;dr: Information is just a representation of what someone wants to do. "I want to kick you" it represents a person's thoughts, but it is not actually the person's thoughts, it just represents them.

Derek has anyone ever challenged LaPlace about knowing the past by knowing all the  details of a system?  Being able to predict the future makes perfect sense, but I don't see how that would imply you would necessarily be able to extrapolate backwards.

For instance in a game of chess, where there is a forced mate, or there are only a few pieces left it becomes increasingly simple to calculate all possible variations but this offers no description of how the pieces arrived at the current position.

Likewise If we were to imagine a universe far advanced towards an eminent heat-death, even assuming perfect knowledge of what's inside the remaining black-holes, it doesn't seem logical that we could necessarily calculate the combination of worlds that once were.

Mathematically put
the limit as known information about everything in the universe approaches infinity,
the known predictability of everything also approaches infinity or conversely, the 
randomness or rather unknown chaos, approaches zero.

In English, if you knew everything, nothing would be random because the premise
states you know everything.

I used logic similar to this when I founded generalized Differential Data Compression
in the 1990's.     Start by having say a million blocks of common information based 
upon reading or knowing the entire stream of data.     To compress everything
without any loss, choose the best matching block and then only process the
changes to make it exact.    For incoming blocks too radically different, simply
give up and read in the whole block.     Using my latest algorithm and code, not
the one published in DDJ and not the one stolen by Microsoft, I managed to get
about 2% compression on a video stream of just static on a TV screen.

Why is that possible?    Because inherently there is some predictability to the
solar flares, cosmic radiation, magnetic influences, etc. which comprise the static
on a TV screen.

As my Master's Project on data compression proved, there is no single method
which works best for all data.    However, if one were to create a library of say
a billion methods, and then pick the best one for any sample, compression 
would be optimized.    

I make this conclusion based on my project which used just 10 different methods
on 1000 different data samples, surprisingly yielded results with the best method working only 23% of the time.    The top three successful methods were LZW, my differential approaching and simple run length coding.   Also, as sample sizes
grew larger, the probability of compression increased and the amount of
compression also increased.

Translating into English, don't knock Intuition for its is a complex, albeit not
understood, massive system of processing information.    It's success or
failure will depend upon the healthiness and functioning of its physical
components and connections in the brain.

True, I agree.  One must anticipate the unexpected.

"The string that contains the maximum amount of information is just a random set of zeros and ones. … You could not predict any of those digits by looking at any of the other digits."

Well, that's true for the all-zeros string, too. If I told you the first digit was a zero, you wouldn't know without a doubt that the second digit was a zero. If I admitted the second digit was a zero, you wouldn't know anything about the third digit. Furthermore, the all-zeros string can hold just as much information as any other string. The first zero might mean, "I'm coming home for dinner." The second zero: "We didn't get any mail today." The third: "The oil in the car needs to be changed." These are all meaningful pieces of data if they were communicated by an intelligent agent in a language that would be understandable by another intelligent agent. But a random selection of ones and zeros that does not represent an intelligently communicated thought or idea is not meaningful and therefore is not information.

"You can continue shrinking a file down until what you're left with is totally random."

Wrong. The compressed version of a file is not random. It's actually deterministic and therefore predictable. Given the original source data and the compression scheme, you can generate the same compression result every time, so there is nothing random about it. And, given the compressed data and the decompression scheme, you can recover the original data every time. It's a certainty. Randomness, on the other hand, implies a lack of predictability.

While I dig the Vsauce video, "What is random?" I'm not so favorable to this sister video. It seems to me to be full of non-sequitors and equivocation, especially in their interpretation and application of Shannon's information theory. Although their examples about LaPlace's demon, and video compression, are clear and accurate, much of what they present seems to be the result of their own hasty philosophical reasoning rather than reporting something that comes from careful research and thinking (despite that they thank a host of experts in the video's info box).

For example, as I understand them, they make the following four claims which are jointly inconsistent (note: '=' designates 'is'):

1. information = order
2. order = regularity
3. randomness = lack of regularity
4. pure information = maximal randomness 

To draw out the inconsistency, consider the following derivations:

5. randomness = lack of order [from 2 + 3]
6. randomness = lack of information [from 1 + 5]
7. Thus: pure information = maximal lack of information [from 4 + 6]

But that (referring to 7 above) is absolute nonsense. At least one of 1-4 must be false.

As a result, I suspect that this video will confuse and misinform YouTube viewers much more than it it will clarify and enhance their understanding.

But perhaps it is I who is mistaken, having misinterpreted their claims. If so, I'd appreciate (polite) clarification. The video has the potential to be interesting.

Thanks!

Hello Veritsium.  May I introduce you to the concept of a code.  There are many systems of codification, or ways of representing information.  For example if you have a number Five, there are various ways you can encode it using numerals (note not numbers, numerals).  We can use our common decimal numeral system and represent the number as such - '5'.  Then again we can use a binary numeral system and encode it as such -  '101'.  NOTE: the information stays exactly the same.  What has changed is the code.  The binary system has more digits in it.  That doesn't make it more information.  It is simply a different way of encoding the same information.  

Compressing a code does not reduce the information, or purify the information.  The information remains exactly the same.  From the foundations of this basic error the entire edifice of your video is built.

Let's agree that what we call randomness occurs at a quantum level.  Electrons in the brain observe this behavior and perhaps this is enough to apply randomness to our thoughts, which we're assuming are electrochemical functions of the brain.  I love this thought, but as soon as you climb the scale of energy to an aggregate the size of a molecule, this idea of randomness changes (which is exactly what an electrochemical function is doing).  When you approach the size of a cell, its affect - even less.  My poor usage of the words "you" and "approaching" refer to a hypothetical change in scale, or energy level, or a ratio/relativity between two points on a spectrum of size, a spectrum of compounding aggregates (the atom to the ant, if you will).  Do you see what I'm trying to get at?  
The cell itself exists where it does to the entire universe.  It's incredibly tiny particles may not have a definite position, but to the universe, the cell is always going to be there through its creation, until its logical end.  Randomness as a concept, sure it makes sense, pure and abstract, but the true physical term randomness, only applies to the quantum realm.  I say "only" not to discredit the quantum universe, but rather to paw at your information theory with practicality.  
But why stop there?  Why not question randomness further?  I mean, why couldn't our inability to simultaneously see location and velocity of a particle be due to an unknown force carrier that causes disruption?  Can we be certain of this tiny world that we can barely measure?  I don't think we can say that randomness is proven. 
And I'm curious... what do you make of the Double Slit experiment?  I mean, when single photons are sent one at a time they land on the wall in seemingly random locations, but the resulting aggregate, the interference pattern that results every time is mathematically predictable.  
So does randomness exist?
Personally I believe it does, but we may never be able to prove it.  Hence, we don't really understand it.  BUT, the reason I believe it does exist is simple.    
Does order exist?  If we agree that there is a direction towards and away from order, then we must agree that just like any spectrum, there must be an opposite.    
Can one exist:- without the other?  Can there be a "yin" and no "yang"? 
The patterns of the universe point to a resounding "No!"  
Thus the question you posit along with your brilliant friend Vsauce are part and parcel.  We are describing single parts of a spectrum and hence we can't understand what we're seeing, unless we look at the "bigger" picture, at the "whole."  

Our perspective in the universe is our greatest gift and our greatest limitation.  
  
Please debate if you will, I would love to hear your thoughts.

I have an issue with your proposition that information = entropy.

Highly compressed information is not random. Unless you are willing to assert that "if u cn rd ths u cn gt a gd jb w hi pa" is a random string of alphabets. 

How much information do the strings 001001001 and 011101001 contain respectively? Exactly 2^9 bits. In both cases. You have to ask 9 'Is this digit 0 or 1' questions to construct either number. And no, you are not allowed to say '3 x 001' because that requires your viewers to have cached knowledge of the number '3' and the mathematical operator 'x' to work. You cannot discount the pre-installed information to make your argument stand. 

If you were to show a baby 011101001, you can reasonably expect the baby to scrawl 011101001 on a piece of paper. However, it is highly improbable for a baby to see '3 x 001' and write 001001001. You have to first teach the baby the meaning of the number 3 and the mathematical operator 'x'. Not to mention a language that is required for you to explain those concepts in the first place. In a sense, the total amount of information contained in '3 x 001' is vastly greater than 001001001 or 011101001. If you were to use the most efficient way of transmitting both strings to a completely blank CPU, for example, you would need the same amount of information, i.e. 2^9, for either string.

Randomness does not make a piece of data contain more information, it merely makes it impossible to use cached information to decrypt a data of similar size.

Encoding a random sequences requires the maximum amount of information to specify since the receiver can not predict it, This is not the same as maximum entropy being information.

One problem is that randomness is really a process rather than a state. You can have a state in a state space that was generated by random process and in which we see no evidence of deterministic processes in its generation.  With no pattern would have to to specify every bit for transmitting that information to another person. Nevertheless, once you knew that pattern, it would have no degrees of freedom so its entropy would be zero.

But this is a trivial case. We are interested in patterns that can create interesrting phenomena like life or videogames. Those have very low degrees of freedom before they break, so their entropy is low, but sent as an encoded stream to a naive observer they would be unpredictable and therefore contain a lot of information.

Let me give an example. Lets take the following number sequence 5058223172. That is part of a larger sequence in which we believe is random. Nevertheless, it is produced by a wholly determinist process and if I were to tell you that it was the 131-140th digits of pi, you could easily predict what came before it, or after it. Every digit is exactly specified, but I transmitting it as a series of digits to a naive receiver makes it wholly unpredictable, maximum randomness, while generating aand encoding it has no degrees of freedom, no entropy, but still requires complete specification of each digit. Once a reciver understood those were digits of pi, he could anticipate an arbitrarily large number of them and so there would be no entropy.

Hmmm... I need to think about this more but I think there are two take home lessons here.

1) Predictability and therefore information content of the stream depends on the observer.
2) An existing pattern has no degrees of freedom so it can not said to have entropy. Entropy is more a measure of the number of equivalent states that something can transform into rather than how mixed up the current state of an object is.
3) the degrees of freedom that a system that are equivalent, depends on the definition of equivalence.

The problem with this video is that pure information is not randomness.  Yes, you could compress something (for example, an image) down into basically a stream of random(ish) bits, but those bits are not the image... all you've done is extract the minimum information to form the image and then moved it to the decompression algorithm.  I mean, that stream of bits is completely useless without the information in the decoder.  And, the information in the decoder is a set of rules, which is order, not randomness.  Information really is about order and patterns.

Daniel Dennet gave a lecture about Determinism and Free Will at Georgia State University a few years ago. He said that the conversation about Determinism as it relates to Free Will is a red herring - it simply doesn't do anything for Free Will one way or the other. On the one hand, the standard argument goes, if we're determined and our decisions couldn't be otherwise, then how can we say they are freely made? On the other, how can any completely random element of our decision making process be something we do? It's random - it's not a product of your will, but a product of quantum fluctuations. If we define Free Will by referring to randomness, then that concept loses everything important about it. For instance, in ethics we often say that in order for someone to be morally blameworthy for an action, they need to do that thing of their own Free Will - it's not your fault if you were under mind-control. But if a Free choice comes down, ultimately, to only randomness, then how can we blame someone for Free actions? They just got a bad roll on their decision making check.

I agree with Dennet. I think that the conditions for Free Will are unrelated to the ability to do or be otherwise, and that quantum indeterminacy does nothing to save it from Determinists. If Free Will has any intelligible, cohesive meaning at all, it lies somewhere else.

Another interesting thing is to consider "flatland". This is a world where everything happen in a geometric plane.
If something from the space goes through the plane, the livings will see some random stuff spawning, growing, shrinking, skewing and rotating.

Hold on now. If I could create a function that will increase entropy in a string of bits, but my function is wholly predictable, then doesn't that mean entropy CAN increase with only the information that came before it, and nothing "new"? My function turns 00100010 into 001011001, and my function turns 00101001 into 10110001. Entropy increases, yet my wholly predictable function is increasing it.

The interpretation this video gives of the second law is a common misconception. The Gibbs entropy (which is the thermodynamic version of the Shannon entropy) is actually a conserved quantity, whether in classical or quantum mechanics. It is the experimental entropy that must always increase, that which is associated with an experimenter's lack of knowledge of the system's internal state. Laplace's demon would never see the entropy increase because he isn't bounded by the same practical limits we are... so no, information isn't being "created". It's not even meaningful to "create" information in a quantum theory where time evolution is unitary.

Okay... you are making a logical fallacy called the Fallacy of Equivocation. To elaborate, you use entropy to mean... chaos, but in science it means something else(a system's ability to do work, which is further defined as using force to move objects over a certain distance) then use a scientific law with your definition of 'chaos.' To put this in prospective, I'll give a couple of examples. Let's imagine a room that is freezing cold except for a very hot corner, as time progresses the heat is more evenly distributed leading to a decrease in chaos as there is more uniformity, yet an increase in entropy as there was work that can be done with a hot corner then a room of uniform temperature, for example... wind. To apply entropy to the universe, a totally entropic universe would have no 'clumps' of matter, meaning we have a uniform spread of particles of equal temperature... which sounds an awful lot like your example of a binary sequence, 001001001001 which you state has very little information.

An interesting video but I would have to disagree with much of the content.

Yes, information is variation, all statisticians and mathematicians here would agree. Yes, information can be compressed via techniques such as singular value decomposition for example, which would help us reduce say 10 variables into 5 without losing much information exhibited by all 10 of them.

While some information such as white noise cannot be compressed, this is where I disagree with the video. While noise and random patterns do not actually convey any information to us, and the very reason it cannot be compressed is because there is no information in there. It has no meaning, it explains nothing and it's absolutely useless. Note that the definition of "information" is "what is conveyed or represented by a particular arrangement or sequence of things."

As for motion of all particles in the universe, the reason it cannot be predicted is because it follows what is known as "Brownian motion", i.e. random motion. We cannot predict what is random because it is random. There is no known relationship between the movement of these particles and any other observable factors.

It seems that there is some confusion in many of the comments between free will in the more traditional sense and strategy/opinion. Whether I choose cherry or chocolate ice cream would not be a matter of free will, but environment and genetics. Whether I take my computer to a repair shop or throw it out a window to fix it is not exactly free will either, but problem solving. Free will tends to revolve more around self VS environment and environment VS environment changes. For example, whether you wish to see another suffer is determined by genetics and/or environment (almost always and). Whether you will find a way to make others suffer as a result of your desire to see them suffer would be where one would make their case against the traditional sense of free will. Ultimately, it comes down to whether one 'supports' good or evil, but in a very vague and abstract sense of both words. What variables one will put out into the environment. Here I must separate hedonism from priority. We all act based on priorities, one cannot get past that. But we do not all act on desires. One should also recognize that desires have an overwhelming effect on priority, but one would have to make the case that it is deterministic before free will can be ruled out. Take for example martyrs. Different martyrs desire different things that are typically related to an ideal (promotion of a religion, protection of life, refusal to speak against an individual, etc). They desire life, and they desire what is related to their ideal. They may desire life more than their ideal, arguably, yet they prioritize their ideal above their life. Or maybe not. But this is where the discussion starts not "I know you won't jump out of a moving car, therefore you don't have free will." Every religion since the beginning of time has recognized judgement as being separate from free will, and on a basic neurological level we know that different types of decisions are made by different systems. Free will does not apply to all of them.

There are some misinformation here. Saying entropy = information is false.
Entropy is technically a quantity that measure how effective we describe a system. Entropy = the amount of missing information, or amount of uncertainty given the way we describe the system. If we only know the initial state of the ink in water, after 0.1 seconds the state is practically the same (entropy is low), after 10 hours as the ink mixes with water, the amount of uncertainty is high, entropy is high.
The 2nd law of thermodynamics just says that given only the initial information about the system, the amount that we can predict decreases as time goes by, that is because entropy, or the amount of uncertainty, goes up.
In making a quantum measurement, you gain information, the entropy is actually DEcreased because of this. In fact entropy is 0 when you have perfect information about the system.

The definition of "randomness" and its connection to entropy and information is a philosophical issue. The reason for this can be seen when you compare your claim: that order is less random than disorder; e.g. a string of 0's contains less information than a complex string - and is thus more ordered, with the the claim that the universe will reach maximum entropy and all hard drives will eventually read strings of only 0's. Equating information with entropy is not the issues, for that is a mathematical one, the philosophical issue as you may see lies in equating information with order. If your hard drive is more ordered by containing less information, you conflict with the universe being less ordered with less information. In the first case low information equates to high order, while in the second it equates to low order - implying the heat death model that is. The philosophy would pick up by defining information with regards to your standpoint, as in it is relative to you. If you're more complex than the system (hard drive model) you'll consider its information density to rise with entropy, but if you're less complex (universe model) you'll consider the density to decrease with entropy. There is an analogy to this in your bit string example; it 'appears' random, until you know the code.

Just reinforcing, this 'unmovable' state may have either a 'formated' disk or a data with meaningful data, so they are completely independent.

Your definition of random seems to run into the problem of observability:  The claim is that random is the most information because it can't be compressed, yet as an information system engineer, the moment you actually generate this random information, it becomes compressible. In this way, random is only non-compressible so long as it remains un-generated... the moment you record it, I can design an algorithm to compress it, much in the same way that quantum behavior resolves to a known state once you observe it. So the only truly non-compressible form of information would be a quantum nibble: that is, an undefined byte of information which is indeterminable as 0 or 1. I can't compress that, but on its own it is anti-information (we call this "corruption" if it happens to your hard disk)  it means less than null because even null tells me the bytes aren't used.  In this, information is not simply pattern, but rather, pattern with some utility (a quantum nibble can be information if it is null, because its utility is known).  The compressible parts of a video are those with the least utility.  The more utility a pattern has, the less you can compress it and maintain a state of "information" therefore, there is a point of video compression where you lose the ability to recover utility-bearing portions, and at exactly that point, information decreases as randomization increases.  If you accept this pattern + utility view, suddenly, information has a second component: the reception of the information.  Tax law has both pattern, and utility... when received by the correct party (for example a college student trying to maximize his grant potential)  but when delivered to a homeless person who begs for their food, the utility is so low as to render it akin to white noise (actually white noise has high order and utility to a sound engineer in certain circumstances, demonstrating that it is a specific kind of information, casting doubt on your claim that it is random, but that's a whole other can of worms!).  Because of this send/receive nature of information, it is not enough to have a pattern, it is important to also understand the surroundings and impact of the pattern (or even non-pattern): in summation, a dice roll holds a very different potential for information on a craps table than it does when accidentally dropped on the floor by a two-year-old.

If you knew the position of all matter, energy, velocity, acceleration etc you would know the future.  I used to think this was so but started questioning this determinist viewpoint when I learned of the vacuum energy.

Regardless of quantum theory's inability to show where a particle is while showing its movement (evidence given in this video), which is a good reason to shoot down determinism,  matter can also appear for brief periods of time and annihilate which can affect what happens in the universe on a vast scale.  Hawking radiation for example.  

I don't believe anyone has been able to determine the location or quantity of this vacuum energy appearing in small regions, so for now this provides the randomness to our universe as well.

The origin of the entropy I believe is not attributed to the quantum uncertainties. Instead entropy is purely a statistical phenomenon. In other words entropy always increases (the directional characteristic of physical events exists) because,  the other way (in which the entropy decreases) is highly unlikely to happen. It is not a consequence of any physical law. It just that the probability of occurrence of that event is incredibly small. (The probability here is a mere statistical probability and has nothing to do with the quantum uncertainties). More over when we are using the word "universe" it would be better,  for this discussion, to use it in a thermodynamic sense (i.e system + surroundings) rather than the cosmological sense.

First: HUGE fan.  I think you're doing great, and important, work for pop. science, and I'm an enormous advocate of educating the public about science.  Second: while I do not entirely agree with the thought process presented, the interpretations are pretty interesting.  I would like pose the following question:  In the case that the universe is destined to expand forever (density of the universe is below critical etc...) then, given enough time, every particle everywhere will decay and after a REALLY REALLY long time, the entire universe will decay into ubiquitous background radiation.  This jives with the 2nd law of thermodynamics, even on an intuitive level (particles decay just like ice melts, right?).  At this point, all of the universe will be comprised of photons of a particular wavelength (background radiation), and this is where I find conflict with your interpretation.  The information necessary to describe the universe in this state is not exactly vast.  In fact, there is so little information that time itself ceases to have meaning.  As there is no possible way to measure time beyond this point, one could interpret this as t = infinity (since all times after this point are indistinguishable).  To me, this seems contrary to the information-entropy equivalence interpretation presented.  Thoughts?

Side note:  I have always thought of information, on the most fundamental level, as being based, not on order, but on disparity.  It is the distinction between one thing from another that gives information its meaning.  For example, If I tell you a hat is red, that's not going to mean anything to you if you don't know what black, green, yellow, white, or aquamarine is and how they differ from the color red.  The simplest example would be binary information, as 1's would have no meaning whatsoever without the understanding that they are not 0's.  Further, knowing the distinction between 1's and 0's allows one to interpret an endless series of 1's differently than an endless series of 0's; two codes with precisely the same ORDER, but different meanings due to the DISTINCTION between 1's and 0's.  
Now, interpreting the fundamentals of information as distinction rather than order, may seem like nit-picking, but following this line of thought, I think, leads to dramatically different conclusions.  Specifically, following the distinction line of thought, one could argue that information and entropy have an INVERSE relationship, rather than the direct relationship presented above.  I would love to hear your thoughts on this.

The second of thermodynamics states that the entropy of a closed system can either stays constant or rises.
Though entropy in physics is defined by the amount of information you lose between describing every particles position and velocity and just describing its macroscopic (global) properties.

For instance, water at absolute zero has a null entropy because water molecules will form a cristal network in which knowing a single particle position will allow you to guess every other particle position (high level of compression). So saying "I have 10g of water at absolute zero" has the same information content as describing the position of every molecule, hence no loss of information, hence null entropy.
If you melt that ice, entropy rises strongly,which tells us that describing liquid water only tells us so much information about average velocity and position of every molecules. Big loss of information on the system equal big entropy.

When entropy rises, information drops.

If you take information theory, which has its own definition of information and entropy (Shanon entropy), it defines entropy as the contrary of information. A source with maximum entropy has minimum Information. In this context, maximum entropy means the most likely.
A signal with high level of information is a signal that is unlikely. Stated differently, information quantifies unpredictability.

High entropy means predictable (noise)
High information means unpredictable

You might have gone too fast on equaling those two different notions.

You're assuming that if the future and the past are predictable then information is constant, but that is not necessarily true.
Take for example John Conway's "Game of Life": A perfectly deterministic game with simple rules, where you insert an initial state of black squares into a grid with white squares (basically a- 2D grid with ones and zeros), press play and watch what happens. In specific cases the system will be stable, but in most cases the little drawing you've put in there at the beginning will get bigger and more chaotic and maybe suddenly get smaller and vanish completely.
The point is that the disorder and information can change even in a deterministic system, and that "knowing the state of the universe at any one time" DOESN'T MEAN "you also know it's state at every other time as well". you can put a bunch of particles in a physical engine and press play, and the information could change. Even in chemistry (that like every other science tries to predict things) where entropy is used a lot, they predict if a reaction will occur or not (although chemistry is not exactly precise...).

This perspective on information is not accurate. Information is not entirely random, or it would have no meaning (i.e. no informative value). Information consists of complexity (which has characteristics similar to randomness) and specificity (which has characteristics similar to patterns). It is the combination of these two elements that produces actual information. (see work by William Dembski, Ph.D from University of Chicago)

The problem with this video is that it espouses a materialist perspective, which states that matter and energy are all that truly exist. From this perspective, it is forced to choose randomness as the source of information. Randomness has never been observed to produce information at the levels necessary for what we know exists within the universe. This view is, by definition, not very scientific since our known evidence uniformly points against the possibility of randomness generating large (or even modest) amounts of information. (see work by Stephen Meyer, Ph.D. from Cambridge)

Furthermore, this view is essentially a view known as scientism, which believes that knowledge can only be gained through scientific means. The problem with this view is that the view itself cannot be scientifically proven, which causes it to be self-refuting. It is obvious that some knowledge can be gained without the scientific method, such as the fact that that it is universally observed that human beings are ultimately moral in their outlook (see work by Christian Smith, Ph.D. from Harvard). If you disagree, consider that you have made an essentially moral claim by stating that I am wrong in my perspective. 

While I still enjoyed the scientific aspects of this video and have thoroughly enjoyed numerous other Veritasium videos, this video attempted to use science to address some philosophical areas of our existence and did not do it well.

I do not like this video as the word "Entropy" is used wrongly. It is said here that the following string 000000000 is low Entropy. This is incorrect and should be considered as a state of high Entropy. Entropy increases when there is a lower amount of possible different setups of a determined element and in this case it is one. If we changed all the numbers around, we would still have an identical string (carrying the identical information). By adding one different element, we have increased the complexity of that string, we have lowered it's Entropy : The string 1000000000 has 10 different possible results if the numbers were shuffled around. It has a lower Entropy than the previous one.

So, to be short: The higher the randomness the lower the entropy.

Why is the state of is entropy so favourable?  You mention quantum mechanics as one source of entropy, but the second law of thermodynamics would still be true even without quantum physics (provided our universe still behaved the same way otherwise).  All systems, physical and chemical tend to more disorder.  The creation of entropy can be the driving force of a reaction, even if the reaction consumes rather than generates heat.  There's also a theory that life exists because, though it seems ordered, the biosphere generates entropy more efficiently than a lifeless earth would.  I've heard explanations in the past that "it's a fundamental mathematical law" because if you have (for example) a given numbers of ones and zeros which can be in any order, there are more potential disordered sequences than potential ordered sequences.  This sort of explanation makes sense to me in that if I throw a deck of cards up in the air, they're more likely to land in a mess than in an orderly pile, but it doesn't explain why entropy is such a powerful thermodynamic force.

So some common misconceptions should be cleared up.
1. 2nd law of thermodynamic : For closed systems the entropy of the system will never decrease. It therefore can remain constant. In fact this basically true for are universe then almost all of the entropy of universe is in the CMB and this does not increase.
2. Entropy is not exactly information(They are related), entropy measures the number of available states. So as a system evolves in time more State become available through interactions.
3. QM is a completely deterministic theory and not random. If you know the Quantum State of a system you can predict how that state will evolve in time, this not probabilistic. The  probability comes in if you know the system with one set variables(Say momentum) but you want to express this state in another set variables(position) this requires measurement, and this measurement will have a probabilistic distribution to it, because there are more then one configuration of state the in one variable that can describe a unique state in another. However this is very important, taking a measurement does not necessarily increase the entropy of the system. What actually increases the entropy of a system is interaction which change the energy distribution of the system. So for example in a Stern Gerlach experiment the number of states available is two(spin up, spin down). Measuring this State for the Z component  does not increase the number of states it just destroy the information about it's spin in the other direction. But putting an Ice cube in contact with a metal plate does increase entropy because energy from the plate will be redistributed to the ice.

I don't agree that information = entropy.  I simply believe that you can represent phenomena with data and the data will have certain patterns in it.  Some data will have less apparent patterns.  Everyone knows there is a risk of data loss due to compression.  Perfectly compressed data is not purely random because there has to be instruction included within the data for decompression.  If you compress to such a point where even these instructions are missing, then your data has lost its meaning and you're no longer conveying useful information.  So one should not say that information is order or entropy, information is information.  Information is data and how the data can be interpreted.

However, one remark: The string of digits shown at 4:05 could in theory be compressed (unless you say we have to stick to binary information, then it is indeed as compressed as can be, but in the previous examply repeat(001) was mentioned so I guess binary is not a must for your example).

You simply need to agree on a dictionary and a word length, say three digits in a row. Each possible combination receives a new key and thus the string can be shortened by replacing three symbols at a time with the new key.

Consider the following our dictionary:

00 = X
000 = A
001 = B
010 = C
011 = D
100 = E
101 = F
110 = G
111 = H

If we split up the zeros and ones into blocks of three, we get the following:

110 101 010 010 000 111 011 000
110 000 010 001 000 011 011 101
110 001 101 101 001 100 100 110
100 100 000 101 010 111 110 110
001 001 110 000 100 011 111 110
101 110 111 001 001 00

We can then replace each block by a new key from our dictionary.

G F C C A H D A
G A C B A D D F
G B F F B E E G
E E A F C H G G
B B G A E D H G
F G H B B X

This could even be repeated until there is no more way to reconstruct the initial string of zeros and ones using. For this, the text would need to be longer of course and dictionaries should only be agreed on once.

I think complexity can be said to be how many semantic patterns can be noticed with in something, and randomness itself is a semantic pattern. The semantics are in our head, not in absolute entropy. Thus complete order and complete chaos are both perceived as being pretty simple, as both can semantically be described by a single pattern. It's like sand on a beach, it's pretty random, and each square foot is different, but it's all perceived as having the same texture. Adding seashells makes it more complex, and we can notice seashells on the beach, even though they are more orderly than sand.

Out of curiosity, why does he constantly keeps saying that the Universe's entropy is increasing. FYI, It's not(Kindly check inflation theory)! Also for those of you, who have a misconception about entropy, it's not defined by disorderness. It's defined as the measure of disorderness of a state. For example, If i supply energy to a physical state, in principle it's entropy should increase, since disorderness increases. Yes and no! For instance, how many of you are familiar with 2nd order Phase transition of ferromagnetic materials? For those who are not, what basically happens, is that there exist a critical temperature around which upon increasing the thermodynamical variable, i.e temperature, Entropy starts decreasing, because evidently, the dipoles(or spins) starts alligning in some desired direction around this temperature, thus decreasing the measure of disorderness or as one would say, decreasing entropy. If one just states that disorderness decreases, then he/she has a general misconception.

Everything is explained beautifully and totally logical, except for- 5:54 (and the free will part, but I get your point).
You're assuming that if the future and the past are predictable then information is constant, but that is not necessarily true.
Take for example John Conway's "Game of Life": A perfectly deterministic game with simple rules, where you insert an initial state of black squares into a grid with white squares (basically a- 2D grid with ones and zeros), press play and watch what happens. In specific cases the system will be stable, but in most cases the little drawing you've put in there at the beginning will get bigger and more chaotic and maybe suddenly get smaller and vanish completely.
The point is that the disorder and information can change even in a deterministic system, and that "knowing the state of the universe at any one time" DOESN'T MEAN "you also know it's state at every other time as well". you can put a bunch of particles in a physical engine and press play, and the information could change. Even in chemistry (that like every other science tries to predict things) where entropy is used a lot, they predict if a reaction will occur or not (although chemistry is not exactly precise...).

When the Chinese philosophers originally theorised yin yang what I think meant was the idea of order vs disorder. If you think about it our entire lives centre around this concept, It explains almost every aspect of human behaviour I mean all religions at the core have a fundamental dedication to order. The belief in a meaning of life is in fact a belief that there is order to our existence. If we consider religious organisations and their patterns we see that consistently there masses or processions involve a sense of establishment and similarly with other non-religious organisations there is an obsession with order. If we take the Nazi/communist rallies for instance, some described them as awe inspiring religious experiences. Why? Because it was a display of structure, of symmetry and order. This may have something to do with the fact we are fundamentally ordered. Our lives can only exist because of the ordering of molecules into finite structures which form DNA which allows life to reproduce itself and grow. Perhaps that explains our infatuation of order. Order represents life itself and perhaps deep within the core of our programming is a demand to maintain structure so that we can continue to exist. It also explains why things that are disorderly are often associated with death. There is a conflict with in all of us between a need for order but also a yearning for disorder. This explains humans desire to destroy structures and humanity’s obsession entropy and with fire (which in essence is the disordering of the molecules of the substance being burnt). We enjoy the Idea of Anarchy because it adds entropy to our lives, we desire freedom because freedom in actuality is lack of order to our life. If we think about the kind of things we associate with rebellion and anarchy I am immediately drawn to rock music, which centres around a distorted, often chaotic guitar melody and riff. War often involves destroying structures, people’s homes and lives. Why do some enjoy this experience?  because they are disordering the elements of people’s lives that were once ordered. Perhaps this explains why those who go to war or even start a war are those who are “outcasts” who have no place in structure of society.  By destroying structures they are providing themselves with a capability to re-order society to better suit them. What ancient Christian and Islamic writers describe as evil is often that which causes disorder and chaos and many of that which is considered goods creates order and provides people with a meaning or purpose to their lives. We fear darkness because we cannot process what we see into ordered structures.

An indeterministic Universe would be a shame. Although it is important to appreciate quantum behaviour as it has been "mathematically" described, one has to appreciate how it was once thought (before the rational mind was established) that everything was at least partially random and things happened arbitrarily.

I feel it's important that physicists and philosophers at least try to scratch beneath the surface of probabilistic quantum theory to try and find definition and reason, much as our ancestors have done so before. Calling it probability is the easy option, and it may well be the correct one, but as has been stated in this video, we can never be sure if something is random.

Probability is just a way of describing an outcome of an event for which we did not have enough information to predict. If determinism is truly absolute, it may be hidden by our inability to detect certain other universal entities.

I'm neither particularly religious nor particularly atheist.  But science is a religion and has random as their god.  It is very useful at this point in history for many things - and statistics and averaging is very useful - however, it has its limitations.  This is where I prefer a viewpoint of Engineering over Science.  Avoid the randomness issue altogether and stick with what we can work with.  Work around the stuff we don't know yet.  Statistics and averages can't build a machine, but careful attention to detail, can.  We can't yet predict where the moon will be next month for certain; only an average.  We have an awful long way to go in measurement and in our formulas.  It's far easier to predict things that are far away from us than it is to predict things that are close at hand.  They're fun and useful as approximations but they are nearly always wrong as we come up to whatever the event in question is.

As always a very interesting video, but I am afraid that some of your statements and conclusions were not correct or at least debatable.
First the identification of information with entropy: The definitions you used for information and entropy were a bit to simple.
As a physicist I would state that entropy is proportional to the number microscopic states that generate the same macroscopic state.
Macroscopic state refers to a set of macroscopic quantities like pressure, volume, etc. that describe a system, whereas microscopic state refers to the exact position,
momentum, etc. of the particles in a system. In general there are many microscopic states that all form the same macroscopic state, but the exact number differs from (macroscopic) state to state.
Let's consider the example a series of zeros and ones:
The macrospcoic quantities would be the total numbers of 1s and 0s.The microscopic state would describe wether a digit is a 1 or a 0.
An example: The macroscopic state "1x 1 and 1x 0" can be generated by two different microscopic states "01" and "10". This would be a state of high entropy.
The macroscopic state "2x 0", on the other hand, can only be formed by one microscopic state: "00". This is a state of low entropy.

Now, let's look at information: The total amount of information needed to describe a state in the above example is the same for all states: 2 bits.
What changes is the amount of information we can gain, if we know the macroscopic state beforehand and then learn how the microscopic state looks like.
If I knew the macroscopic state is "2x 0", I would automatically know how the microscopic state would look like: "00". I would learn nothing new. (Remember, this was a state of low entropy!)
But if we considered a state of high entropy like "1x 1 and 1x 0", we wouldn't know exactly how the microscopic state would look like: It could be "10" or "01".
So we would gain new information about the system by learning how the microscopic state looks like.

In this sense and only in this sense it is valid to say that entropy equals information:
Entropy equals the information one can gain, if one already knows the macroscopic state and then learns about the microscopic state of a system.
Entropy equals NOT the total information stored in a system.   
This especially means that an increasing entropy does not imply an increase of the total information stored in a system! (as you suggested for the universe)

Information vs compression...
Funny that everyone considers only "flat" 3d space for the information... you think that if you strip information to minimum which carries whole information you reached minimum point? Its simply not true. Because you can provide a pointer, time reference where that information were or will be stored and then in theory by that reference recover whole information! Its common practice in programming to transport only pointers instead of whole data, and we know that time in our universe isnt just an abstract void passing by. We know time can be bend, slowed down or even stopped . We have hard time to use this knowledge yet but in information theory you could say:

"If one make a movie, then delete it and only provide time reference when that happened. Anyone wanting to see it will need to look into specific time/space and will be fed with data required"

Now then you may say then this reference is minimum information required but again you may compress reference to certain precision, you may bundle references... you may make a dictionary of the references and leave it in time and space somewhere and then provide only dictionary key to the others... storing single pointer to whole cluster of references to almost infinity amount of data...

then again is this key minimum data? or key of keys of keys of keys..... No
You may forget your key, but because it existed somewhere in time and space it may be found by searching through, in same way as we may find something we were not even looking for in our world.

So is the very existence of thing minimum information? Why would it? existence is nothing more than realization of some idea (in very generic way, not only human idea)
So for example someone could have good idea but live in time/space when that was impossible, by finding out this idea with new technology one could make the very same idea real.

We are now in the point where not only we dont need to stopre/provide information about things but those things could simply even not be realised. But we could go even further. Many ideas realised in our world are result of cascade of ideas not a single one. By parsing time and space to find idea we may decide to look for collective ideas instead of instances. Those are things which never was invented fully by a single being but their parts scattered across many individuals or even their possibility in the time and space.

I could go on... but simply removing redundant data from information doesn't make it size of planck.

Is random data really not further compressable, not even in theory? Maybe it is.
Here is an idea: For each finite amount of so called "random data" there may exist a function that (if used in the right way) can generate this data. I am especially talking about random() functions, since these functions can generate all sorts of output. If this is possible, then I think the random data should be able to be further compressed. How? Just remove all the data and use the function as an instruction instead. This would also mean that even random data may contain less "information" than thought. Of course this is more a theoretical statement since in practical use it should be usually impossible to find a proper function (and all needed initial conditions *) when only having a bunch of random data as a clue. Well, at least in most cases.

(*) Of course, knowing the initial conditions (like the "seed" for the function) is really important here. Otherwise the output of the function is unpredictable.

Sigh. It's so sad to see some of the top "science video bloggers" on YouTube being so wrong about so much fundamental knowledge. But it's common for psychological reasons. I'll explain:

The easiest thing to talk about first that you're getting wrong is free will. It's BS, whether one even concedes that the universe is deterministic or not has no bearing on free will being fundamentally an impossibility, see the wiki article on "dilemma of determinism." If your actions aren't determined (by you or whatever else) then they're random, meaning you still have no control over it, so the idea of free will is a total paradox and only exists through cognitive dissonance because it makes us feel better to think we are in control and we don't have to be logical about what we believe, like so much philosophy. But it makes your videos more appealing to people I guess.

And aside from that you were so close to being right, realizing that the universe would be completely deterministic if information was constant. But then you had to bring in the entropy argument from the second law of thermodynamics. Problem is, it's just straight up wrong if you're trying to say it applies to the universe. It doesn't. The irony of course is that you gave us the easy way of explaining why you're wrong when you said the universe doesn't "stir itself up." What are nebulas, stars, planets, heck what happened between the big bang and today in general? Did the universe need some outside force to get all this order instead of a giant uniform soup after the big bang? No of course not. There are several ways to explain why this is. The obvious one is that the second law of thermodynamics was never meant to be applied to the universe but people offhandly still think it does, ignoring all the fundamental forces that invalidate it that led to ordered systems like stars, planets and people. And the laws we know of explain this and all of them are completely deterministic... which you seem to know right up until you decide to ignore all that.

You understand how compression works and that there are higher order patterns that explain why there's a lot less information in the universe than we think (we think being the key word), even things like the equation that describes gravity and how it can govern so much of what happens in the universe, and you decide not to take the inductive reasoning step ("This is what all the evidence says so the universe is deterministic") and instead say "but maybe the reason why we can't compress quantum mechanics further..." And here's how you can tell you're wrong. You run to the edge of our knowledge to try and back your position (quantum mechanics) which is very common for your position because there's basically nowhere else to turn to. Your argument whether you realize it or not is an argument from ignorance, a standard informal fallacy, that's demonstrably wrong because you're basing it entirely on gaps in our knowledge which runs against all of the things we actually do know. Also, this belief is cognitive dissonance as well if you understand macro physics and probability theory.

QM is still new and you're making a completely invalid assumption in saying our understanding will never improve (total assumption) therefore it's the source of randomness that we conveniently can't find in anything else we understand except a law that doesn't actually apply. You can demonstrate you're wrong because of basic probability theory (see: law of large numbers, law of significant figures). QM can't actually be random because if it was then we couldn't have models that work on the macro scale AT ALL. Probabilistic equations couldn't work either. That hypothetical supposed randomness would only aggregate as you use equations to model the macro world based on the micro equations but guess what, we don't see chaos in the macro world. QM behaves exactly as it should given that on that scale you need exponentially more knowledge to be more in the ballpark of what the right answer is (see chaos theory). Einstein called it right because he knew what he was talking about, our understanding just isn't there yet when it comes to QM which you, and most other people, fail to concede.

In other words, take the extra step with respect to information and patterns instead of ignoring it. You have the principle right. As you mentioned, we know how to compress videos to 1/1000 of their size already and someone has estimated the english language to be 70-75% redundant... well after we make more powerful, intelligent computers that can see higher order patterns that we can't even imagine why wouldn't it tend to 1/infinity and 99.9repeating% like in a limit function? That's kind of the historical precedent for how our understanding progresses (again, see chaos theory).

But of course, the reason you've committed all of these fallacies is simple. It makes us feel better to know we are in control and that everything can't (theoretically) be completely predicted. Problem is, that's wrong.

@Veritasium 

"I am not suggesting you have conscious control over your decisions as even current research shows we become conscious of choices after we make them."

I don't think the question is quite as simple as "don't have conscious control" or "do have conscious control." I mean, we get influenced by a lot of things, do we not? Environment, mood, physical state, mental state, etc.

I think it's sort of like being the captain of a ship on a stormy sea. We can't control the waves that are pushing us in every direction and threatening to pull us under (environment and subconscious) - but we can process the information we have in ways that will (hopefully) have a good outcome (conscious thinking).

So for example, if you're weighing options - vote for Red candidate or Blue candidate - and you extrapolate through thinking that Red candidate will be most in line with your values, then your thought process would (I would think) influence your subconscious decision.

Of course, the thinking you do will itself be influenced by pre-existing notions, the limited information you have, etc.

Point is, why we act and how we act is messy because of all the factors at work, and statements like the one you made (though I don't necessarily disagree with it) make the process look clean and straightforward.

Nice video Derek! But a couple big quibbles. You don't gain information when you measure the electron's position. What you gain in position information you lose in momentum information. That's Heisenberg for you. On a more general level, all we know about quantum mechanics right now is that it's unitary. That literally means that a quantum state has the same amount of information in it at all points in time. If the universe can in fact be described by a single quantum state, it MUST always contain the same amount of information. The second law of thermodynamics, and the collapse of the wavefunction, only appear true to us because we are a subset of that very same quantum system.

If we don't have free will, then no one could be accountable for their actions.  If free will were even proven to not exist, then there could no longer be punishment (or justice) for anything, since everything would be predictable and not in any way related to what we choose.  Therefore, no crime would ever be the fault of the one who committed it, it would be due to the predictable chance that the particles in that person's brain lined up and caused those thoughts and actions to occur.  This discovery would lead to utter chaos as no justice would take place, therefore cause total entropy of society, which follows right along with the 2nd Law of Thermodynamics. 

But...since new information brought to a reasonable human can cause them to change their thoughts, behavior, feelings, and opinions, then we most certainly do have free will.  Psychology and sociology prove we have free will, it goes a lot deeper then simply particles in the brain lining up in predictable fashion.

Something can be predictable and still random.  It's only when we can control inputs that it no longer becomes random.

If I roll dice, the outcome is random.  Even though if you could calculate the energy applied to the dice, the contours of my hand and the material the dice roll on, so on and so forth, you would be able to exactly predict how the dice will land.  But, unless the one rolling the dice is able to accurately control all of those variables, it's still random.

So, even though our thoughts and choices might be predictable at some quantum level, unless the inputs are controlled by something, the results are still random.

I don't think the core concept of this video is right. All zeros on a hard drive is not "no information' - it is exactly as much information as all 1s, or completely random numbers. And randomness is also not "maximum information". Also, compression has nothing to do with how predictable bits are from eachother - compression is about identifying similar pieces of information, and tagging what places in a bit-string they are. And a compressed file is not "completely random". Describing entropy as "disorder increases" is an incredibly misleading way to describe it. An example of maximum entropy of an empty room is a completely homogenous, uniformly temperatured room of air. Would you really call that "disorder"? No. It is simply the most likely arrangement of those particles by far. Veritasium usually does a good job, but this whole video is very poorly thought through

To arrive at the conclusion that randomness is how the universe works just because of the unpredictability of future events isn't very convincing. The increase in entropy of the universe is not random, in my understanding of the word. Let me clarify.
If a (any)characteristic can be applied to an event, the randomness of it at least goes down on it's degree. In this case, entropy always increases and that the entropy will increase, is predictable.

Most randomness we observe can be predicted to a degree in such a way that all the possible events can be a part of all encompassing "possible event universal set" talking in terms of venn diagram.

The compression of information mentioned in the video refers to the reduction of this universal set to a smaller subset of the possible events.

Randomness, at leastfor me, should be an undefinable term in physics and something which cannot be a part of an All encompassing universal set. Chaos, in this sense, is not random, but a magnification of the possible set of events.

On the other hand, certainty is definitely not the way to go thanks to uncertainty principle. So it appears that we do not have two faces of a coin, two extremities, which is Randomness and certainty- but a reality, which can only be one of the possible outcomes of an initial condition, not random, not certain.

Edit: Should probably have read the first comment.

Even a deterministic being would, however, have effective free will. For example, 1 computer can indeed plot out the path of 1 particle. 2 would likely be able to plot the path of 2. If 1 billion could, between them, perfectly predict a 1-billion-particle system in 2 times real time, one would expect it to take 4 billion to predict the interactions between 4 billion particles in real time. Above that scale, the actual physical ability to predict the future of a chaotic system slows down. The Time complexity of the system isn't linear, it is O(N^2). Similarly, predicting not just what happens when a synapse in a deterministic being's brain fires or does not, but predicting whether it will fire as as intended or not with 100% certainty, is extremely computationally expensive, potentially requiring one to calculate O(N^2)-complexity functions on every last particle in the entire observable universe. This is all without quantum mechanics even being involved.

So for free will to appear, you only need an illusion of randomness. You only need it to be effectively infeasible for anything within the universe to make predictions. As far as a human is concerned, video game characters can have free will if their behavior is pseudorandom or governed by programming that is too complex for them to predict accurately in real time.

A quote from I forget whom: "If the brain were so complex that we could understand it, we would be so simple that we couldn't."

In other words, the required amount of computational power to guess what will happen goes up faster than linearly with the system's complexity and the amount of external input. Practically speaking, there is totally unpredictable input. Light from deep space, for example, it being moving at the speed of light, is untraceable. Determining when an astronaut will suddenly be hit by a Gamma ray and where they will be hit is fundamentally not something that is possible to do within the known laws of physics, even ignoring quantum mechanical effects. That has effectively produced randomness. Maybe it damages a specific few cells in their brain? Maybe not. It may be deterministic, but that information has escaped us, never to be retrieved until it is too late.

Freedom is the insight into what is necessary. To paraphrase Hegel.

Shannon is interesting and useful in a narrow sense for some fields, but not really the best definition of information, and very flawed for other fields.

Let's say you start with something completely random, and try to decompress it. Well, chances are you won't end up with something understandable or useful. Only something that was understandable or useful to begin with, then compressed, will actually decompress back to something understandable or useful. This distinction is important in some fields, and requires defining information as more than merely randomness.

At one point you said that if you removed all redundancy from the English language, then it would be "random". (This, of course, applies also to information contained within images/videos, etc.)   However, while it may *look* random, it still contains information.  And something else that looks random may not contain information. 

Information comes when something (even perhaps a seemingly random string of values) follows rules of syntax and grammar.

The random noise you showed on the screen might very well be the result of some "random" process, and it would not contain any information.  But random noise on the screen produced by removing all redundancy from a video still contains the information it originally had whether there's redundancy present or not.

A probing video nonetheless.  Always enjoy them!

Your point at 5:55 isn't valid because of algorithmic information theory.

Entropy appears to increasing in our universe, but if the state of our universe were determined by say, the digits of pi at an arbitrary starting point, it would also look like the entropy of the universe was increasing, although at it's foundation it is just an algorithm with a fixed level of Kolmogorov complexity, albeit increasing Shannon entropy.

For the universe to not be deterministic, the state of the universe would have to somehow arise from an uncomputable real number (as opposed to the computable irrational reals such as pi, or e), and proving a number to be uncomputable is computationally impossible (I have a proof for this if it isn't immediately obvious), so unless we assume there exists some type of hyper-computational physical mechanism that humans can somehow access, it will be impossible to ever definitely prove whether the universe is non-deterministic. It is also, strictly speaking, impossible to prove whether the universe actually is truly deterministic, but for different reasons.
