I really don't like the comparison of information to entropy, because while unpredictable, information has meaning, it represents something. For example, DNA, it has certain patterns, but also contains completely random sequences, however still contains the information to create something familiar, like a cell, or for the example in the video of binary, the data that does not follow any discernable pattern still contains information and meaning, a meaning that is used to create this video. If there is a sequence of binary numbers that is completely random, then it will not create something, it does not have meaning, and cannot be classified as information. It would be meaningless. Secondly, if you were able to know all the information in the universe, you would be able to know the exact rate at which entropy is increasing. The amount of information in the universe is constant, but this information is being altered in a fashion that consistently tends towards entropy, in compliance with the 2nd law of Thermodynamics. So I personally don't think that information can be compared to entropy.

I disagree with your assertion that quantum mechanics is the driving force behind the increasing entropy (and information) of the universe. Surely a purely classical system still exhibits this property. Take for example a sealed box of gas, which begins in an initial state where all the gas is on one side. This is an extremely orderly state with little information. Ignoring any quantum mechanics, and treating the gas molecules as 100% deterministic classical little spheres, this system will indeed evolve over time into a state where the gas is spread evenly throughout the box. Even with no randomness allowed a simple, deterministic system has experienced an increase of entropy and information that came from "no where".
In fact I'd even say pointing to quantum mechanics as the driving force of entropy is just plain incorrect.
Chaos theory is basically an entire study into the fact that deterministic, nonrandom systems can indeed behave very complexly, even to the point of spontaneous self-organization. In fact, chaotic systems have the property that a minute perturbation (even of size arbitrarily close to 0) in initial conditions leads to drastic differences in outcome. Put another way, given some final state, even a deterministic system cannot accurately "remember" its initial conditions if it is chaotic, which sounds a lot like entropy and the arrow of time to me.

EDIT: Okay I ranted before I finished the last few seconds of video, but my point still stands--quantum mechanics is unnecessary to explain the increasing entropy of the universe.

I have an issue with your equating entropy to information, as it is a big part of your argument it does not immediately work for me.  I would argue that information is about something and that there are two types.  One that is used to define something, and thus is used information. The other is gained from something once it is defined, and is thus is derived information.

  For instance the letters of a sentence would be the used information, while the meaning of the sentence, and thus what sentences will follow is derived information.  Thus a cohesive well written text would develop more derived information than an ill written text much like this one which would bananas be bonkers yo.  The last part of that sentence adds nothing by itself, it is an increase in the entropy of what I am saying.  Yet its effect and amount of entropy can be measured with the used information of this text.

While used information does go up in accordance with entropy for the sake of describing it this does not hold the same with derived information. I would argue that derived information goes on a bell curve in accordance with your statement that we are drawn to that information which is in between nothingness and pure entropy.

Derived information is used to figure out what comes next and can be as simple as, 'where will this object be in the following instant.' 

With this I argue that despite entropy requiring more used information in order to be defined, its product and thus its derived information, is simple.  Looking at heat which is a commonly used way of defining entropy, we can predict it.  Its derived information is that it will spread, it will do the same thing over and over.  It is predictable: it is a pattern and can be, as you said in the video, simplified.

While we look at a human which we can define with far less information than random. Thus the used information is less.  However, considering the very nature of the medium through which we speak, can humans preform only one action?

The overly complex and bloated entropy model of information does less than the sleek ingenious human model, which gives more information, for less.

To sum up my argument, convince me once more that "entropy=information" because I am not convinced.

This was genuinely thought provoking but I think you have failed to make an important distinction between maximum information and maximum information density.  When information is compressed, there comes a point at which it cannot be compressed any further but, despite its appearance, this compressed information is not random but has a structure defined by the compression algorithm and the information itself.

As entropy increases, information decreases.  At the heat death of the universe, there will be no structure and no information.  This being the case, we dlon't need to look for extra sources of new information.

One way I understand the workings of the universe is with a coin. This coin is a €2 coin and it is spinning on the side. This coin can't spin forever and it will fall onto another face in an effort to organise itself but this coin also cannot decide which way it wants to organise itself. If the coin was the only thing in the universe, it would spin forever because it is impossible for the coin to make a decision by itself. However, this cannot be the case because in fact, there are other things in the universe and each particle has an influence on the coin in some way. The coin would be forced to make a decision because of the circumstances it faces. e.g a hand slams the coin onto the ground. The coin is not conscious of its decision and neither is the person who used the hand but once the smoke clears the universe is informed of the decision. We learn that a decision took place and we also know what the decision was. We could guess the face that the coin would land on but we couldn't know for certain so to find out, we did a procedure that forced the coin to stop so that we could know. We couldn't guess what the outcome would be and we still couldn't guess the outcome after 5000 repetitions of the same event. But was it the same every time? Thats for you to decide.

You are kind of forgetting time. If the universe could be summed up by an initial state, and laws about how the state of things develop over time, then the universe would appear to have an increasing amount of information from one moment to another, but only for someone who does not know the initial state and all the laws.

EXAMPLE: If the universe was a spread on a pool table, then the initial state is very easy to describe. It would only be some balls positioned in a tight triangle, while another ball was moving at some speed towards this triangle. However, 2 seconds after the ball hits the triangle of tightly packed balls, one would need a LOT more bits to accurately describe the state of the table (without the initial state). But fact is that if you knew the initial state, and all the laws, you would still only need the same amount of information to describe the state; the initial state, the laws, and the time, t, of the state.

This fact is demonstrated in most compressed videos. A movie containing a thousand images, can be compressed down to a lot less information than what the sum of all the images individually can be compressed to. You kind of mentioned it yourself in the previous video.

Also, there might be another part of our universe that is decreasing in entropy as our part of the universe is increasing in entropy. If the smallest bits of our universe were a googol times smaller than the smallest particles we know, then the information at this incredibly small scale could be decreasing as the information moves "up the latter" to the universe we know and love. That is sort of the nature of information and patterns. We see difference on one scale at the expense of difference on another scale. We see a dog and a cat instead of soup of chaos and seemingly identical soup of chaos. In complete chaos on the particle scale, humongous monsters of patterns like humans would not exist. There is probably some scale at which each cubic of this scale seem identical (be it a googol times the size of the observable universe). But as time goes by, it is easy to picture that patterns of greater and greater size emerges, and so that the "scale of homogeneity" would increase. And the average information within each cubic-(something smaller) individually would decrease as a necessity for this to be the case.

My point is that all the information you need to produce any state in time of the universe might be less than what you need to accurately describe any persons DNA, this video, or a pair of socks for that matter :P ... Am i right?

So if free will is an illusion, whether or not the universe is random or deterministic, there is no "danger" of making the "wrong" decision to believe that actual free will exists, right? Whether or not choice would be out of our control due to determinism or uncontrollable randomness would not change the fact that the only "right" choice is the one that happens, and the only possible "wrong" choice is non-existent, because it never happens. As such, if your belief conforms to reality, you can't take the credit for it, and it becomes somewhat meaningless.

On the other hand, if actual free will exists outside the realm of science, then "right" and "wrong" choices both exist. Don't mistake this as an arguing from consequence, I'm just pointing out that it logically follows that the only possible "right" decision is to believe that actual free will exists, and the only possible "wrong" decision is to believe it doesn't.

Also a purely classical universe (with no quantum level) would create entropy. In that case the increase comes from the statistical effect that there are many more ways (microstates) that something can be disordered than ordered. A simpe statistical effect. Entropy expresses how much we can distinguish in a system at the macroscopic level, so it is an at least partially subjective quantity.

This mirrors the information divide between system and observer in quantum mechanics, but the former does not derive from the latter, but both from the same universal statistical effect at different levels of description. Classical randomness arises independently from quantum randomness, for classical randomness is in principle reducible (Laplace's demon), while quantum randomness is truly indeterminate.

Would this not render time travel basically impossible? Or perhaps confirm the many worlds theory?

I mean, if the universe's "future" is, as yet, undetermined, then wouldn't "skipping" to the future have to force x amount of time's worth of random quantum generation to occur, for that future to exist? And wouldn't this fundamentally make the "future" you traveled to essentially disconnected from the present you traveled from?

If 3 people traveled to a predetermined "future" from 3 different "presents" (or even the same present?), would this not create 3 totally random, different futures that would be totally disconnected from each other, and therefore that "present"? 

This sort of suggests to me that time travel may just be an impossibility, or that in order to time travel, a whole new existence has to be created.

(This all refers to "instant" time travel, rather than relativistic time dilation.)

Thoughts?

I really liked this video, gave me so much to think about haha. The whole talk of entropy and information made me recall something that Sean Carroll said in a video while discussing Naturalism with other philosophers and scientists. I think it may have some implications concerning the things you say, but then again, maybe it doesn't, I'm no expert. Still, I think it's a really beautiful analogy, so I guess I'll share it anyway. 

In the video he says something like this: You can Imagine the universe as a cup of coffee with milk. The initial system is one in which the milk and the coffee are completely separated, the milk on top and the coffee on the bottom. A system such as this would be very simple to describe (it has little information). Then you can imagine someone shaking the coffee with milk until it's a perfect mix. The resulting system would also be one that's very simple to describe, you could just say the whole thing is evenly mixed. If the first system is analogous to the early universe (low entropy) and the second system is analogous to the late universe (maximum entropy), then you can imagine a middle step which would be analogous to the universe we live now, the middle universe(?). In this system of coffee and milk, you would find the mix halfway to becoming perfectly even, this stage of the system would be very hard to describe (a lot of information) because it would require you to take into account every little detail, for example, a tiny sector in which a spiral of milk with a very specific size and shape curls into the coffee. He goes on to say that in a way, this tells us that one would expect some kind of complexity to arise every now and then from the natural process of the second law, and maybe us humans in our amazing complexity are kind of like that spiral of milk, still not evenly mixed.

A couple of questions emerged from contrasting this words with what you say about information being the same as entropy. First: Isn't it correct that a maximum entropy system would be very simple to describe and therefore low in information? And wouldn't this make entropy and information at the very least not directly related? And second: Is there anyway we can guarantee what we call information isn't always limited by the way we choose to describe a system? Like how little information the temperature of a room is compared to the vast information necessary to describe the energy of each molecule in the room. I think it might all have to do with the poor understanding I have of concepts such as entropy, but I thought my concern was worth sharing.

Again, thank you for this video. You have a really awesome channel, keep up the good work.

Also I've always thought that a deterministic universe wouldn't be entirely predictable as the predictor would have to contain everything (i.e. actually be the universe and what affects it). This would be because compressed information only parses from a certain perspective and otherwise needs to be decompressed. To simulate the not completely decompressed existances in action and reaction faster than real-time would require the equivalent of a processor with a thread for every re/action at any moment connected to the storage of the equivalents of everything with FTL communication (reverse entanglement?). It would also need the capability for another thread group to rewind/fast-forward to a particular moment and create a compressed stasis from which a query might be answered. The collective to create this machine would need to sustain and dedicate itself and the construction long enough and already have an encapsulated moment to be fed in from the distant less entropic past. The machine would then have to fast forward the archival portion to the present and keep going as the likely limit of foresight while indexing reference points to rw/ff the query portion from.
As un/likely as we are I don't think this would ever happen.

There is a great book series by Isaac Asimov "Foundation". The premise of the series is that the mathematician Hari Seldon spent his life developing a branch of mathematics known as psychohistory, a concept of mathematical sociology (analogous to mathematical physics). Using the laws of mass action, it can predict the future, but only on a large scale; it is error-prone on a small scale. It works on the principle that the behaviour of a mass of people is predictable if the quantity of this mass is very large (equal to the population of the galaxy, which has a population of quadrillions of humans, inhabiting millions of star systems). The larger the number, the more predictable is the future.

In system theory (i.e. Electrical Engineering in my case) there are both "causal" and "acausal" systems. The outcome of causal systems are strictly determined by their past, while the outcomes of acausal systems are determined by future outcomes. Suppose we grant that the entire universe is basically causal, even despite quantum randomness and chaotic amplification. What should be noted is that the brain is basically a model of awareness that allows us to form predictions about our environment. Our neocortex lets us (fallibly) predict the future. It is a "memory-prediction framework". This means that even if the entire universe was causal, evolved brains can still very strongly emulate acausal systems. You don't need to scale quantum effects to explain free will. As if "randomness" was a viable candidate for "will" in the first place.

Even though these quantum events make determinism impossible, you could argue that people still don't have free will.

Everyone agrees that if the universe was purely Newtonian, a person would not have free will because his behaviour and actions are simply the results of the specific state of the atoms that make up his brain and the rest of their biological machine called life. And if time was reversed for one minute in this hypothetical universe, the exact same minute would happen if played back again (determinism).

Quantum events, as they are called in this video, do alter the results of those newtonian processes, but us humans are, ofcourse, not in control of these events.

I find that terminology can be a barrier to proper comprehension.

The term chaos is a bad term, at best based on the false dichotomy which is stated to exist between order and chaos in the universe - a paradigm of thought which has persisted in human intelligibility since ancient times, forces typically represented by gods.

"Chaos" theory is a misnomer because as it is defined, although it is not perfectly predictable by human techno-scientific apparatus, the particles in a system are fundamentally deterministic. A deterministic system cannot appropriately be described as chaotic. Chaos is a term more accurately related to the degree to which a thing or system is understandable by human beings - we don't understand it therefore it is chaotic (akin to the I don't understand therefore God did it). Our understanding of quantum phenomena is merely imperfect due (in my understanding) to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. What is referred to as "Chaos Theory" should be re-termed something like "the theory of probabilistic order determination," albeit less elegant of a name.

For this reason the term random is also an inappropriate term since the randomness of a system is only apparent randomness due to the inherent limits to precise observation / barriers to comprehension.

The association between entropy and information gain is also odd and counter intuitive. Some of the equivocated terms seem based on incorrect assumptions and/or poor logic

The sequence of equivocation seemed to proceed as follows

Info = Order
Pure Info = Randomness
Randomness = Disorder / Entropy

Logically, pure info must be equal to pure order

Pure Info = Pure Order

So it follows that:
Order is disorder
Order is entropy
Order is randomness

Huh?

This demonstrates why improper terminology and un-examined logic creates misunderstanding. Word play doesn't get us anywhere with understanding things like free will or how the universe works. We need to always realize that our intelligibility of existence is only ever this - limited by our cognitive, physical, and technological boundaries. To understand free will I find Heideggerian philosophy informative and personally assent to non reductive physicalism as a way to comprehend the emergent nature and origins of consciousness and it's faculty of free will.

However I think that example with perfectly compressed video isn't a good one for showing that entropy = information.

Perfectly compressed video will contain bits with no patterns, however only bits in that order and amount will add up to make original file. So you can't say that they are random.

Let's say that there are 10 bits in a compressed file. Only 1 sequence is valid, but not any other. And there are 2^10 possibilities. Fact that only one is correct amongst many others brings order in to this, thus "canceling" the entropy.

Somehow the probabilistic behavior of quantum mechanics results in completely predictable behavior outside the realm of quantum mechanics. If you couldn't know all past and future states of the universe because entropy (or "information") were increasing over time, then you should also have errors calculating the motions of planets and stars. But we don't.

I'm only an amateur physicist, and by no means an expert, but I'm assuming this is because the probabilistic behavior described by quantum mechanics "evens out" in non quantum objects. Perhaps it's the same way that rolling a perfect die would still show the same number of rolls of each number, given enough rolls. The second law of thermodynamics is something we have observed. It doesn't mean that it's theoretically impossible to predict the future, just that we haven't managed it. If you know the universe is one of a set of possibilities, and you predict the future from them perfectly, the later set will be the same size. If you approximate at all, the set will grow, causing an increase in entropy.

The idea of randomness in quantum physics is all dependent on wave-form collapse, which would violate several principles physics seems to follow and has no supporting evidence. It always seems to happen after the waveform decoheres, and it would be impossible to tell if the waveform is collapsing.

According to the Many Worlds Interpretation, the only randomness is the laws of physics, the boundary conditions, and the anthropic effects. You know you're one of the many observers in the universe, but you don't know which. If you know the waveform at a neighborhood of this universe, you can calculate the waveform of the entire multiverse.

"Custom is the great guide of human life." - David Hume.
Inductive inference is extremely flawed. We observe and unchanging pattern, and infer that it will continue in the future, tacitly assuming that nature will continue to behave in a uniform way. For example, we see the sun rise every morning, and we infer that it will rise again tomorrow. But is our claim that nature follows this uniform pattern really justifiable? Claiming that the sun will rise tomorrow is not a demonstrative statement, as claiming the opposite involves no logical contradiction. Nor is it a probable statement, as we cannot experience the sun's future risings. If there is never any rational basis for inferring cause and effect, then what justification do we have for making that connection? This is simply "Human Nature."

Hence Information isn't randomise.  As entropy increases, it increases randomise in the universe and decrease the usable information.  If you changed the letters in "pure information" movie, you will then get noise in the original decompressor.  Hence Entropy is the opposite of information.

It kind of bothers me that people always use dice as an analogy of randomness. It may not be completely predictable, but that's not quite the same thing. If I was rolling dice, what position the dice was in (in reference to how I was positioned), the shape of my hand (skeletal structure, muscular structure, how much I bent my fingers/moved and positioned my hand when rolling), the air circulation in the room (or at least the part of it my hand containing the die was occupying), the shape of the exact surface it lands upon, elevation it was dropped from, etc. are all determining factors. If I played a game of monopoly with 3 other people, the game would play out very differently if it was one person rolling for everyone every time versus everyone only rolling for themselves, even if they were all rolling with the same dice on the same table in the same room on the same day.

If you consider an irrational number, such as pi, you find that the previous digits give no additional information after the future digits. The digits of Pi are entirely random..., except they are not. You can determine the digits of pi by using equations which are fundamentally independent of the order of the digits.

You could spend a lifetime  trying to find a way to predict the future digits of pi using the previous digits and you will fail in the same way that you would fail if you tried to predict the solution of a quantum event using some kind of previous information. I think the nature of quantum events is not that there is a mystical randomness, but that the solution is not a function of time. I believe it is in our tendency to organize events into past and future that makes the quantum event seem "random". Although we may experience from past to future, I don't see any reason that the universe cannot exist in both time periods at the same point in space.

I think it's good to differentiate between quantum mechanics and pseudo-chaotic phenomena like free will. True, quantum particles are non-deterministic but zooming out on a macro scale, say atomic level, almost all products of reactions can be anticipated with some given conditions, which are deep-rooted principles for typical systems we use like internal combustion engines or nuclear reactors. In a way, that has dominating nature in our own free will as well. Thinking is a result of ionic imbalances in neurons resulting in graded action potentials, causing a synchronous firing in groups (nucleus or ganglion), with some sensory input. Therefore, it's safe to say that all biological systems are predictable, that's why we all have our own distinct anticipatory behaviours, annexed by our DNA, which is a mere information that encodes us all. As for colossal masses like planets, stars, galaxies and quasars are mostly governed by law of gravitation. The attempt to get to a unified field theory is to succinctly state the equation where all physical forces can be characterised and that, I believe, is predictability despite randomness. It could only mean gathering all information of the universe (i.e not an 'isolated' system unlike say Earth) at a specific point in time to predict the future, which is impossible. Bottom line, I strongly doubt if quantum mechanics is the one responsible for increase of entropy, but instead something macroscopic than that.

Technically, when you compress something up to a point of total randomness, you're not "purifying" the information by removing redundancy. Instead you're changing how information is represented. Effectively you move it from "storage" into decompression algorithm. Because only knowing this algorithm it is possible to restore original knowledge. And different algorithm will produce different knowledge with same "purified" data as an input.

Information is randomness is entropy. Sure. But thermodynamic entropy isn't really random, is it? Thermodynamics in general is an approximation. A simplification that lets us describe incredibly large systems (there are a lot of molecules in that glass of water) in sensible but somewhat inexact terms. If i did indeed know the position and velocity of all particles in a box and had enough computing power, i could predict it's state arbitratily far into the future/past whether its thermodynamic entropy increases or not (if we ignore quantum effects, which thermodynamics does(?)). Meaning the box contains a constant amount of information and Laplace was right.

In part, I hold in de Broglie–Bohm theory stating that all quantum randomness is only the result of our ignorance. We still don't know enough quantum mechanics to know everything that is going on in a region of space. The Schrödinger's equation helps in a lot with predicting the likely hood of systems, but still leaves uncertainty. What is interesting here is the uncertainty principle. It is possible to create something out of nothing for an extremely short time. It can be that a single virtual particle can exhibit an interference that adds to the quantum information in the universe. So essentially, it could be that all the particles/waves are well within the scope of predictability if it weren't for the quantum foam compromised of virtual particles that interferes with everything. My theory is that while the effects of virtual particles are minuscule to well established forces that hold matter together, any wave with small enough interference can be effected by this, increasing its entropy such that it can then interfere with stronger waves to produce bizarre effects such as quantum tunneling.

Let's assume that the universe is totally predictable, for the sake of argument. What happens if I discover the entire Truth and try to predict my own future? Can someone tell me if I've got this wrong?

Logic tells me that if I accurately predict the future, then that prediction must come true. If I see something in my future that I don't like, then I would attempt to do something differently, which means the prediction is false, game over. If the prediction includes me trying to do something differently and failing, then I would know what not to do, game over again. The only possible predictions are predictions that I cannot or do not want to change. Given that I can change any prediction by merely blinking once when I predicted I would not, the only possible predictions are predictions that I do not attempt to change. As such, the only possible future is one where I get everything I want exactly as I want it. That, however, means that I would be able to stop the inevitable, such as the expansion of the sun or the end of the universe. That implies that either A) total knowledge of the universe grants total and complete control over it or B) the future cannot be predicted.

So, if quantum mechanics and nothing is random, and the universe collapses again into a black hole the same as at the beginning of the universe, then everything that is happening now will happen again. It's such an interesting thought, that this sentence, including all fixed typos, has happened before, possibly hundreds of times. Perhaps fate is a true thing.

Say if you recorded the quantum state of every subatomic particle in the universe for the entire existence of the universe and then replayed the existence of universe from the big bang to whatever possible fate the universe has in the distant future. Then you replayed the entire sequence an infinite time all the time recording the quantum state of every particle over again an infinite number of times. You're saying unequivocally that none of those particles would every form a predictable pattern. I say that's impossible. There has to be some level of predictability at a quantum level for their to be any order at all in the universe or galaxies would end up looking like gigantic hot dogs or bicycles.

Interesting! I just want to say something about free will and quantum randomness.

Free will can be defined as the ability to choose freely what to do, why and how. It makes "true" responsibility possible.

If quantum randomness is real it is possible to choose real alternative options (next to imagined ones based on predictions), so our ability to choose becomes really free in some sense. However, people also associate free will with "source control". Source control means that "I" am the ultimate source of my choices. Quantum randomness doesn't explain source control. 

Either way, in my opinion "free will" is just a vague concept based on our intuitions. I experience that I can choose what to do, why and how, so I believe this experience exists, but whether this experience is "free" because of randomness or not doesn't really mean anything to me, and it doesn't seem morally relevant either. :-)

I would have liked to see a better distinction between randomness and contingence. Randomness implies purposelessness (stochastic systems), which would preclude free will (the philosophical bit at the end there). Contingency is undetermined, but not necessarily random. This is the bit, philosophically speaking, that is important for true freedom. (I'm working on a chapter for Routledge Philosophy companion related to this topic, hence my insistence of the terminology).

To be clear, by "free will" I mean that your decisions could not be predicted with certainty, even if someone knew everything about all the particles that make up your body. I am not suggesting you have conscious control over your decisions as even current research shows we become conscious of choices after we make them.

I've given my view on the quantum measurement problem but it's called a problem for a reason. No one has it fully worked out quite yet (or maybe this is as fully as it can be worked out). I am not saying that determinism is certainly false, but our scientific theories and observations as they stand today imply that new information is being generated in the universe and this makes it impossible to predict the future with certainty. Some day this view may be overturned.

To me, for now, time looks like a zipper. Far in the future the possibilities are wide open, but with every passing second time zips up what might be into what actually happened.
Even if there exists true randomness in quantum events in our brains, that does not mean we have free will. Those events are not controlled by us, they don't happen at our will.

I would argue that at any point if you understand every single variable in the universe then yes, you could predict everything else. For example, the mass in the universe is constant, mass cannot be created or destroyed. Since mass and energy are related, this extends to energy as well. Immediately after the big bang in your example, that was all the information a perfect theory would need to predict every single action in the history of the universe.

The only reason we cannot actually predict things perfectly is because we don't know everything. There are still highly theoretical fields that we have no concrete understanding of. Once we do understand everything (which I don't think is possible but who knows,) then we will be able to predict everything that happens or has ever happened. Thus, in my opinion, Entropy only increases in your scenarios because we don't have a complete understanding of every possible model for the universe.

We have no perfect equation.

If you know the starting information and the transformation methods applied to it, you can know exactly how anything will change at any point in time.

"For us really to have free will we need the second law of thermodynamics."
But is that truly free will? On the one hand, we are still bound by the laws of physics, we can't just suddenly "decide" to violate them: every particle that makes up us humans, and the rest of the universe, will still obey predictable laws.On the other hand, quantum events since the beginning of time are, as the video indicated, random.

So wouldn't the answer be that we are in a universe that is deterministic on small scales (predictable cause to effect) but random on large scales (small quantum events at one point in time having large unpredictable effects later on)?

To clarify, I'm putting free will and determinism on the same side of the scale, with randomness being on the opposite side, because I consider any input-output system that can be defined by a law or rule to be deterministic while true randomness can't be described in this way.
